BTW, my biopsies were not done by a surgeon but by a radiologist. For both my diagnostic mammo/ultrasound and biopsies they offered dates that were a few weeks out and I said,"NO". Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 03:38PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Katie, I have a Bard Power Port. It is triangular with a raised dot at each corner. Mine was placed in the little hollow between my shoulder and upper chest. It is only visible in tops that have spaghetti straps. I had it put in at the same time as I was having another surgery so I did have a general but most have it done with conscious sedation. It can stay in as long as needed provided it is flushed/used regularly. It requires no other care once it's healed (unlike a PICC). I also get my blood drawn from it which is a plus. They spray it with a numbing spray before accessing and I don't feel a thing. If you google it and look for images you can see what it looks like. All you see is three raised dots in a triangle arrangement. Mine is much closer to my shoulder than most. Try it! Caryn

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2013 06:44AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Kay, I don't if this question was directed to me, my one bone met is necrotic an I have been NED for almost 18 months. Once bc leaves the breast, it's lurking out there, even if you currently have no active disease, so some type of treatment is used to hold off new mets for as long as possible. NED is not the same as cured, it just means that there is currently no observable active disease. HLB, Yes, since I had only one observable met, rads was a very effective tx and clearly done to kill off the met, not for pain relief, as I had no pain. The reality is, however, that bc is lurking somewhere in my body and will eventually take hold and grow again. Caryn

Posts.Content: May 18, 2014 08:01AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I am sorry that your sister is going through this. Breast cancer, IDC or any other type has many complex variations which effect treatment decisions and, ultimately survival. Since you know little about your sister's bc, it would be impossible to give you specific info. However, to say that chemo and surgery never work and it always comes back is just plain wrong. There are many caring oncologists who do not just want your money. Yes, chemo can be tough (I am told, since I have never had chemo), but there are drugs to make it easier. Are there guarantees that treatment will prevent it from coming back? No, that is the reality of the beast. Wishing the best for your sister and hope you can get her to go for a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 08:49PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Lindsey, As nbnotes mentioned, staging us based on the pathology report after surgery, either mastectomy or lumpectomy. Having  PET scan is, I think, the exception rather than the rule for early stage women. MiraclemileM, I'm not certain about how I feel about PET scans being part of every initial bc work up. It exposes one to unnecessary radiation and doesn't (statistically) increase survival time if mets are found. That being said, I had a PET scan, for non bc reasons, about 6 weeks after my stage IIB dx. Lo and behold, a bone met! No pain, no symptoms so I wouldn't have known it was there otherwise. So, I may not survive longer but I will have known about it longer. Interestingly, my tx has been less harsh then was planned when it was thought I was IIB.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 09:24AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi, I think the very best thing to do is to take whatever steps, short of any self diagnosis or Dr. Google, to allay your fears and worries. This means an appointment with a doctor who has a lot of experience in dealing with bc. As to genetic testing, see if your insurance will cover a meeting with a genetic counselor. Through taking an extensive medical history they can determine if you are a likely BRCA risk. If you are, they will inform you of all of the implications and decisions you will be faced with and knowledgeably answer any questions you might have. There is a wealth of information and experience on this forum but there is also misinformation and here say. Nothing is a substitute for a visit with medical professionals who will consider all factors of your individual situation. Wishing you the best. Caryn
Posts.Title: Complete understanding of what is going on: smart, or madness? ATLgadgetgrrl SelenaWolf

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 10:23AM exbrnxgrl wrote: When I was first told that I had IDC, my first reaction was, " There are different types of bc?" Who knew! Knowledge is a good thing but can create worry if you don't know the specifics of your particular situation. When you know exactly what you're facing then you can apply your knowledge in a specific manner. Yes, there are unknowns about bc, yes you can have mets and not know it but unknowns are very much part of the nature of life. Do not waste precious time on what hasn't happened or what might happen. Deal,with what you know, be knowledgeable and vigilant but worrying about what hasn't happened is only borrowing trouble. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2016 02:19PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Breast cancer is not diagnosed by blood tests or tumor markers. A biopsy is a valid diagnosis. Tumor markers are useful in some cases, not all, but not as a means for diagnosing bc. Breast cancer stages are not "reduced". You don't go back from stage IV to stage II. Your stage IV may become inactive, but once bc has moved beyond the breast to distant organs, the horse is out of the barn. Good nutrition is wonderful but sadly, curing breast cancer is not that simple. You will certainly find testimonials from those who claim diet alone cured them, but you need to decide how much faith to put into personal anecdotes. Wishing your wife all the best.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2013 06:45PM - edited Jan 21, 2013 07:22PM by exbrnxgrl We all perceive pain differently. Your breast will be very well compressed and they will pull as much tissue as possible between the plates. Some find this painful, I used to find it mildly uncomfortable . It doesn't last long. If you are pre-menopausal and experience breast tenderness before your period, schedule it for after your period. Good luck! Caryn

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 05:46PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Posy, I was diagnosed in July of this year. My preliminary staging came from the two different biopsies I had but final staging came via the path report post bmx. The final path report found my IDC to be larger than initially thought and I had 1 positive node. This moved me up to IIb. It was scary and upsetting and there was certainly some temptation to not want to know more. But in the end, the only way I could be an active participant in my treatment was to know as much as possible about my disease. Denial and magical thinking provide brief escapes but in order to fight the good fight you need to be fully informed. You can do it! Caryn

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2014 04:13PM - edited Mar 30, 2014 04:14PM by exbrnxgrl Susan, As you can see, there's much more to,life with mbc than you might think. I should have said, in terms of learning about your disease, to stay away from dr. Google at large, and focus, with your onc's help, on your specifics. The stats that you find online are often several years old and reflect aggregates, not individuals. And while it is true that on any given day there are woman struggling at stage IV, you may have many good times to come (laced with some crappy ones too). When things settle down for you, pm me and we can meet for coffee somewhere on the Peninsula. I will be in the city next Sunday to board the Grand Princess for a week long cruise with my younger dd. I didn't think such things were possible when I first got my stage IV dx but I spent Christmas break in Australia/New Zealand and I still work full time. I do tire more easily, but I'm still here. Take good care of yourself  Caryn PS: If this sounds too rosy, the first months were awful, including a punctured lung. I still have too many medical appointments and I'm stiff as a board if I remain stationery for too long, from the Arimidex, and have gained some weight, but I don't have a foot in the grave yet.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 03:06PM exbrnxgrl wrote: PICC lines require more care after insertion. They are usually used for folks who have more short term IV needs. Ports, although installed with a minor surgical procedure, are quite carefree once healed and require no care on your part. I don't know If PICC's can be used for blood draws, but a power port can, which makes it really nice. For chemo purposes, ports seem to be preferred in most of the US. BTW, I am one of the unlucky few, 1%, who had a lung puncture and I still love my port. My story is on one of the threads (lung collapse after port insertion?) but I can't imagine using my one good side for needle sticks. Caryn

Posts.Title: Concerns about Anastrozole (Arimidex) chris42 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: May 5, 2014 07:23AM - edited May 5, 2014 12:52PM by exbrnxgrl Hi a Ladies, I am in a very different position than both of you, so I am very motivated to keep taking Arimidex, even with some se's. That being said, I have taken it for almost three years. I take it right before bed, so if there is a relatively immediate tiring effect, I don't notice. Overall, I do tire more easily and by the time I get home from work, I'm pretty wiped out (I teach first grade. That could be the problem too ). I have some joint pain, mostly knees and ankles, but it varies and seems to be worse if I'm sedentary. My knees are not very "springy" anymore, so rising from a squatting position is not easy. If only the first grade desks weren't so low! My general advice to anyone who is on the fence about this is to try it. If your se's are bad, you can stop. Despite the minor se's, I do everything I always did . I even climbed the Sydney Harbour Bridge several months ago. Take care. Caryn

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 05:24PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Chris, Certainly do whatever research you need to, that's a good thing! Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: Ok, I may be a little cranky today or maybe just a stickler for concise terminology. I have noticed lately that when people have mets or are concerned about mets, they sometimes say they have bone cancer, lung cancer etc. The good news is that it is not true, you do not have a new primary cancer. The bad news is that your bc has spread to other organs. The main reason why this is an important distinction is that a metastasis of bc will be treated as bc regardless of where it has spread. Here is a brief article that explains this: www.nccn.com/understanding-can... Sorry if I sound like a nit-picky crank, but a bit of education never hurts, right? Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2013 08:35PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Kathy, This is an issue which brings out lots of opinions, sometimes very strong ones. The forum title does mention caregivers and supporters so it's to be expected that some will post here. When they ask for advice on how to help as a caregiver or support as a friend or relative, I think it is appropriate to point them to the caregivers forum. After all , many of us have never been in their position. I am not too thrilled about having to comfort distraught family members. It seems odd to me that they would turn to others who have the same disease, and stage IV no less, for comfort. The other thing is that it is hard to define what might be or might not be an appropriate post by someone who is not stage IV. Sometimes it is very clear when a post is inappropriate here but other times it's a matter of individual interpretation. Never the less, I would hope we are never mean to anyone who posts here when they probably shouldn't . Caryn
Posts.Title: What is metastasis? exbrnxgrl Brendatrue

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: Ok, I may be a little cranky today or maybe just a stickler for concise terminology. I have noticed lately that when people have mets or are concerned about mets, they sometimes say they have bone cancer, lung cancer etc. The good news is that it is not true, you do not have a new primary cancer. The bad news is that your bc has spread to other organs. The main reason why this is an important distinction is that a metastasis of bc will be treated as bc regardless of where it has spread. Here is a brief article that explains this: www.nccn.com/understanding-can... Sorry if I sound like a nit-picky crank, but a bit of education never hurts, right? Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 10:31AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Ladies, Good discussion. To respond to the original question, no imaging method is infallible. This is hard to digest and scary but true. It is also true that finding mets early does not increase overall survival rates. However, these are broad stats over a large group which may or may not be true for individuals. Yes, it is true that the number of tx options you have are limited, but there are many tx available and more coming down the pike. I doubt that anyone, with limited mets, would hold off on tx so they don't use up tools in their arsenal. My mets were discovered by accident, no pain no symptoms, and treated ASAP with radiation and AI's. My bone met is necrotic and I've been NED for 2+ years. I have no way of knowing what state I'd be in had the mets spread or went undiagnosed until symptoms appeared. I consider myself lucky, but I know in the end, I'll be no luckier than anyone else who is Stage IV. So, what do I think of regular scanning? Once a year does not seem unreasonable if you have no symptoms and yes there is radiation exposure. It's clearly not a black and white issue and nothing is infallible, Rosestoeses, Your dx only appears in your signature line if you choose to make it public. The mods do not control this.
Posts.Title: Question about detecting mets when mammo didn't detect cancer RosesToeses Momine

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 02:53PM exbrnxgrl wrote: throwing the kitchen sink at lower stages is not necessarily a great idea given the fact that chemo and rads carry risks. The long term survival rates for early stage bc is clearly favorable , even without the kitchen sink, so over treatment would be ill advised. The "no rhyme or reason" comes in to play with trying to predict who will recur or have mets. Yes, one sentinel node should have put me in a better position, but bc cells travel through the bloodstream as well so node negative or few nodes is not a guarantee either. I actually have no complaints except that my life will most likely be shortened. I know what awaits me but keep on keeping on. At this point, although I never forget I have bc, I lead a normal life.
Posts.Title: Question about detecting mets when mammo didn't detect cancer RosesToeses Momine

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 11:16AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Yes, my tx, and the only TC I have had, is indeed in my signature line ! Rads and Arimidex, that's it. I have never had chemo. This is a very usual course of tx for those who have mets at initial dx (and mine essentially was, since the met was found while I was recovering from bmx) and are ER+. I know everyone is different but my 2+ years have been quite normal save for more doctor visits than most people. I work full time, have become a grandmother and walked my younger dd to the chuppah. I'm going on a cruise to NZ/AUS in three weeks. I know that overall this may not help long term survival, but it's taken very little away from my life and I've yet to have progression. Of course, it't impossible to know what the course of my bc might have been otherwise.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 10:20AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi, I think it's probably difficult, at this time, to predict how your bone mets might effect work. I think it's very different for all of us. I am an elementary school teacher and did take a 3 1/2 month medical leave last year. My mets were discovered during my leave. I had rads to my femur, went on Arimidex and Aredia and went back to work. My employer knew I had bc but I did not tell them I was stage IV and don't intend to until there is a legitimate reason for doing so. By contract I can leave work by 3:15 pm, but like most teachers I rarely do, except on days when I have infusion, scans or doctor's appointments. I have always been able to schedule these late in the day. When I returned to work I tired a bit more easily but what suffered most was my house, not my job! I'm on summer break and have lots of deferred household projects. Wishing you the best. Somehow, we all manage to negotiate this rocky path. Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 07:32PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi etherize, Yes, the multidisciplinary team is the breast care clinic (at least at Kaiser  Santa Clara). If you seek a second opinion outside of the Kaiser system you will not need additional biopsies, mammograms or ultrasounds. You simply have to sign a release and Kaiser will send, or you can hand carry, all slides and films to wherever you are having a second opinion. They do not include their recommendations, just the facts, so the second opinion team can interpret them without any bias. I went to Stanford for my second and their approach (multidisciplinary) was very similar to Kaisers. Stanford was at my own expense. For the record, I have been very impressed with Kaiser so far.- Caryn

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 09:22PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I am so new to being stageIV that I am probably in shock to some extent. I miss the old normal so much and hope to return to some of it soon but I know I can never go back to not having bc. I am not old, 55, but certainly never thought I'd face the possibility of my own mortality in the foreseeable future. Maybe I won't, maybe I will. I still have a lot of hope. I hope to go back to work soon. Not working has really robbed me of a lot of my identity. I love what I do and feel it's important. I hope to have many years to love my first grandchild who will be born in March. I hope to have a fabulous time at my younger daughter's wedding in about 18 months and see her children too. I hope and hope every time I read a bit of good news on bc medical advancements. I hope they will work for me and for all of you. This is how I am coping right now. I know my journey is just beginning and I haven't faced some of the difficulties many of you have but all I have is hope. Who knows? Maybe it's still a bit of denial. I wish you all peace and whatever serenity you can find. Caryn

The primary compensation method used by all of the Medical Groups is salary. Salary generally varies with medical specialty and tenure. Smaller amounts of additional compensation may be paid for, among other things:  In addition, in some Medical Groups, the excess money that the Medical Group retains, if the basic contractual payments exceed the actual cost of care on a regional basis, also may be used to pay additional compensation to doctors and other personnel As you can see, they are, for the most part on salary. -Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 04:30PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Here goes... 1. Yes, I am from the Bronx. We lived on a block full of kids and the streets were our playground. Our elementary school, P.S. 97 was on the corner and most of us walked home for lunch. We live in semi-attached homes with small backyards. Mine had a steep hill and was a favorite sledding site in the winter. You flew down the hill and crashed into the chain link fence which separated my house from Young Israel of Astor Gardens Synagogue. They were orthodox, we were not, but we attended because it was convenient. I dropped out of Hebrew school after one year but my brother had to go the distance to make his Bar Mitzvah. Most girls did not make Bat Mitzvah back then. I am the oldest of three. My sister, the youngest, passed away 18 months ago from a very aggressive uterine cancer. It has been so hard on my parents and I thought I'd just about kill them with my bc diagnosis. Sound horrible but I hope they pass away before me. Losing another child would kill them. I love the Bronx because of the Yankees, the Bronx Zoo and good Italian food on Arthur Ave. My best friend still lives there. My dad owned a parking garage in Manhattan between Little Italy and Chinatown. It was culinary heaven. I rode the subways and buses everywhere and loved the museums, Broadway and the vibrancy of art and culture. 2. My granddaughter is the best! My older daughter (her mother) and SIL live slightly less than an hour away. My younger daughter sort of lives with me but floats to her fiance's house a lot. She is being married in June and he is a great guy. I was married for 23 years and never felt so happy as when I finally told him to leave. Too much to go into but let's just say a marriage can't be made better by the effort of one. I am extremely close to both my dd's and they are close to each other. Both of them and their mates have been a tremendous support during my bc trials and would do anything to help me. I am so proud to have raised such fine young women and know my little granddaughter will grow to be a fine woman as well. I love them all beyond words. 3.Lived at home during college, ran away and joined the Peace Corps and was sent to Afghanistan. Came back from Afghanistan and became a flight attendant for the late great Pan Am. Traveled the world while based at JFK. Got tired of too many roommates and NYC rents so moved to Houston and commuted to JFK for a while. Got married in Houston and my ex was transferred to Northern CA. Lived in Los Gatos, an upscale Silicon Valley town (still teach there) during my marriage. After my divorce moved to a small townhouse near downtown San Jose. Not upscale or chic but there is a library on the corner and I can still grow some veggies and herbs on my tiny patio. Very happy. 4. Rosh Hashonah? Small family dinner. I am not observant but I make my mothers lukshen kugel which I think is the best. Will post recipe soon. I will take the day off for Yom Kippur so I can say Yizkor for my sister. 5. I LOVE my job! It is like a calling for me. I teach first grade now but started out many, many moons ago teaching ESL in high school. I now know that third grade and below is where I belong. I think I have something to offer the kids but each year, they amaze, entertain and give me more than I could ever give them. I love each one and as long as I feel well, I will work. My school community is great and they were also a tremendous source of support when I was dx last year. Their generosity was overwhelming. Anyway, what would I do around the house all day? 6. I am rarely angry, even with stage IV. I don't know why this is. I am quite a Pollyanna so I suspect this has something to do with it. I am very good at making lemonade when life hands me lemons. Also, Afghanistan was once a beautiful country. I want to bear witness to that fact because there are now so few who remember it that way. My two years there changed me forever and I credit that experience for making me who I am.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2017 07:28PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Lillybee, At stage IV, we talk about NED (no evidence of disease) rather than being cured. I have gone for more than 6 years with NED status on Arimidex and now letrozole. I can't, and won't, say my bc is reversed or cured because that could change in a minute. I wish I could give you more positive news, but this is the ugly reality. There are some patients, roughly 1-2 %, who don't recur but it's not known why this happens. I live a generally healthy lifestyle, but wouldn't say I do anything alternative . Enjoying everything in moderation makes me happy and happiness is my goal, whether I live ten more days or ten more years. I know you have a young child (I'm a mother, grandmother and first grade teacher) so our personal circumstances are quite different, but enjoy every moment with your child. Remain optimistic, but be realistic as well. There is no known cure for stage IV bc, but new treatments are being develope. Wishing you the best and hoping that you'll be one of the lucky ones . PS: since you are using so alternative therapies as well as conventional, you will probably never know what has helped, but neither Lupron nor letrozole "reverse" bc. Lupron itself, is not a bc treatment but it's what allows you to take an aromatase inhibitor, like letrozole, if you are pre-menopausal

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2017 03:44PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Someone posted earlier that "the creme" available by prescription is the same as Aspercreme with 4% lidocaine. It is not! EMLA is 2.5% prilocaine and 2.5% lidocaine. It numbs the skin much more thoroughly than any OTC product. This is not to say that OTC creams won't help, but there is no comparison with respect to level of numbness. I use Aspercreme with Lidocaine for arthritis. Not only does it not numb as well, but the effect doesn't last nearly as long as EMLA. Again, OTC creams may be sufficient, but EMLA IS AMAZING

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2018 06:51PM exbrnxgrl wrote: terri, That was so sweet of your sister. My dad once sent me an article about a drug that could prolong the life of those with metastatic disease. Turns out it was for prostate cancer! I had a difficult convincing him that all cancer is not the same. He was sure that if it worked for prostate cancer it would work for any cancer. It is hard, even for our loved ones, to understand not only the fact that all cancers are not the same, but that in the world of any given cancer, there may be many different types that respond differently to different treatments. Actually, it's mind boggling when you think about it. Yes, I think the women on the Ibrance commercials are probably actors, but if you saw me you would never imagine I had cancer, let alone mbc. How we look doesn't always tell the whole story.

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: I know there will be a certain amount of blowback on this topic and there is a part of me that thinks I am a fool for even starting this topic but here goes. Some people have been upset over the Ibrance ads/commercials that show stage IV women happy and going about their lives while on Ibrance. I realize that these women represent the minority of stage IV women, in terms of looking well and carrying on fairly normally, but, they do represent some of us. I am not on Ibrance, but I can identify with those women. Their lives look like mine. I can relate to them. So, although this is not the way most stage IV women live, it is not untrue for some of us. It would be impossible for a commercial to represent every "flavor" of stage IV or to put in a disclaimer so people understand that this is not typical of stage IV, but for some, it is a reality. It's a reality which, I hope, touches more and more of us and a reality which may give hope to others, but within the stage IV community there seems to be some negativity about advertising the fact that some of us are doing well. There is no doubt or illusion that these commercials don't represent the majority of stage IV women and things could turn on a dime for those of us who are doing well but I sometimes feel that as a stage IV minority that I'm not considered a legit part of of things and I need to hide my truth and experience with stage IV bc. I do have MBC and I feel like my experience of living with it for almost 7 years is just as much a part of the MBC community as anyone else's and doesn't detract or distract from those who are having a rough time. I'm ready for the push back, but I don't want to have to apologize for doing well. Bilateral mx 9/7/11 with one step ns reconstruction. Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 12:33PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Lisa, Good questions. I am ashamed to say that some of my memory from my first year of tx has gone a bit fuzzy.  Here's what I do remember :) - initially, I had a PET scan every 3 months. My mo was looking for any and all mets, not just bone. I now have a PET every six months. - when I started Arimidex, I also started monthly Aredia (bisphosphonate) infusions. I had them monthly for the first year and then every three months for the second year. My mo was a bit concerned about se's with long term use. I have a bit of osteopenia in one hip and take extra calcium. I recently switched to Femara, not because Arimidex failed, but because my se's had increased over the years. - if one AI fails, you may be put on another. Each mo views it differently and, most importantly, takes your particular case as the most important consideration in a new tax plan. Good luck tomorrow! Caryn

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 10:28PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Etherize, Drains are not only used after an AND but after mastectomies or other procedures in which a lot of tissue is removed. Fluid would build up in those empty spaces, so the drains, with gentle suctioning action, siphon out the fluid out of your body. For most people the drains are not painful just annoying. I am very squeamish and easily grossed out by stuff but it wasn't too awful to deal with them. They really weren't that gross. Mine were in for 10 days but there seems to be a wide range depending on what your output is. Don't worry about them too much! Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 10:23PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Zohra Jahn, I think there are two different things to think about. The first is how likely cancer is to appear in the other breast, as a new primary. The second is, for some people, the peace of mind that having a bilateral mx brings. It is my understanding that the chances are not great of developing a new primary in the other breast. That bring said, peace of mind is different for each person and a deeply personal choice. Some people can't imagine removing a healthy breast and others can't imagine leaving it there once they've had the experience of breast cancer. Whatever your mom decides, I know you will love and support her. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2013 04:48PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Lily lady, Too bad you can't share those brownies over the Internet! Pattih, I think if a couple of beers and a cheese sandwich helps alleviate stress then that's just what you should do. I was thinking about coffee, which some say is a no-no. I love the smell and taste of coffee, the ritual of brewing it, even the comforting feeling of the warm cup in my hands. I drink two cups in the morning, as I did before bc, and can't imagine giving up such a small but lovely pleasure. I realize that this is only anecdotal, but my sister did everything "right" in terms of nutrition and lifestyle for 30 years before she succumbed to an aggressive uterine cancer. She passed away 4 months after her diagnosis. When she would come to a family party, she would relish some of the tasty treats, like a kid in a candy shop. Then she'd go back to her spartan existence. Was it worth it? In the end, an end that came far too quickly, I think even she would have said no. Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2018 12:13PM - edited Apr 22, 2018 12:54PM by exbrnxgrl Becs, I'm so sorry that you find yourself in this situation at such a young age. It's certainly not where anyone envisions themselves in their 30's. Young women with mbc are often an unrecognized minority. LoriCA, what inspired this thread was actually a thread on a knitting forum I belong to. I believe it was "Alice" who appears to be the proprietor of a yarn store. Knitters sit up and pay attention when we see anything in the media about knitting. The funny thing is that on my knitting forum, many objected to the commercial because they felt that no one, NO ONE, could have mbc and be happy or have a job or any sense of normalcy for that matter. The comments were filled with things like, poor woman, so sad, she is to be pitied, so wrong to show cancer patients that way etc. When I commented that some, but not many, with mbc do have lives like this there was quite a bit of disbelief. One woman asked if, perhaps, I did not understand my dx because no one with mbc lives like that. Umpteen PET scans and bone biopsies have made sure that I understand my dx all too well. I still don't think she believes me! Another commented that I could not have mbc because I was not on IV chemo. I wish!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 06:47AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I had another bisphosphonate , Aredia. I had it monthly for the first year and then every three months for the second year and then stopped. Bisphosphonates are bone strengtheners and prevent hypercalcemia which can be caused by other meds we take such as the AI's. There had been some early evidence to suggest they helped defend against spread of bone mets but that hasn't panned out. In addition to ONJ risks, there are concerns about spontaneous femur fractures. Both of these se's are still uncommon, but mo's are beginning to rethink keeping patients on these drugs for very long periods of time. Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 10:47AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Wonderful news on the scan! Naproxen is not prescription. Alleve, naproxen sodium, is available OTC and most drug stores carry the generic as well. The prescription dose may be higher. OTC dose is 2 tablets of 220 mg each, but dosing is once every 12 hours. I have had some success with it and tend to take it more at night since it is longer acting. I also buy generic ibuprofen (200 mgs. each) and take 4, which is a prescription dose. I do have an iron stomach but I don't use either regularly so I haven't had problems. I know what you mean about the narcotic pain killers. I hate them and rarely take them. I still have left overs from my bmx last year. Hope you can get a handle on this. Chronic pain is no fun. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2015 09:50AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Deanna, Last year's flu shot formulation was one of the least effective in recent years. I was lucky that flu was not prevalent in my area, so that may have protected me more than the shot itself. My school had a really rough time with intestinal maladies last year, probably Norovirus. Let's just say our custodian got way too many clean up calls! Somehow, I escaped, but I am diligent about hand washing. As far as vaccines in general I am all in favor. Are they perfect? Do they sometimes cause adverse reaction? No they're not, yes, they do. But, most people in the U.S. Do not remember a time when the diseases that vaccines prevent were common place. Since the majority of children in the U.S. are vaccinated, herd immunity often protects those who are not (though we have begun to see a breakdown of that). So, the argument that "My child is unvaccinated and is fine"is not a valid one in my opinion (and now, cannot attend public or private school in CA, unless they have a medical exemption). When I was in the Peace Corps, almost all of the diseases we never see here, were common place. They killed, crippled, disfigured and shortened the lives of many. Why? A largely unvaccinated population. How many of us have ever seen the effects of smallpox, polio etc? Rant over 😉

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 02:00PM exbrnxgrl wrote: At this point the BRCA test identifies a very limited number of mutations. There seems to be a good chance that there are others yet to be found. Lily, I had DCIS and IDC in the same breast and was able to have a skin/nipple sparing mastectomy. Easy recovery, one step implants, great results. I know a few other women who had DCIS and LCIS who had skin/nipple sparing bmx, TE's and then implants. Neither of them had issues. It is possible! If you're using this forum as a yardstick, it's pretty stilted as those who have problems are much more likely to post. Does recon cause problems? Yes, for some, no for others and impossible to predict which group you'll fall into. That doesn't make my story or AJ's any less valid. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 04:19PM exbrnxgrl wrote: One of the considerations when doing one step is not wanting to go much bigger than your natural size and, of course, have a skin sparing mastectomy. My ps also added that they tend to get the best results on those who are c cups or smaller and want to stay that way. I had this done, bmx, almost 17 months ago and am quite pleased. As to pain, I can't say it was more or less than the TE route, since I never did that. My pain level was tolerable but I did stay on top of it for the first three weeks, although I got off of the narcotics quickly because I hate them. Advil worked fine and I still had a stash of the narcotics if needed. There don't seem to be a lot of ps's with experience in this area. My ps did only recon, no cosmetic surgery so he was great at it. He did make it clear however that if during the surgery he thought that the one step results didn't look good he would go with TE's. that was the first thing I asked when I woke up! Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2019 07:11AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I think I hold the minority view regarding scans and overall monitoring. My mo operates in a manner very similar to LoriCA’s. My mo does not do tumor markers, but will not hesitate to do a PET if necessary (I have no co-pay). I am in my 8th year of living with MBC and am glad that I scan much less frequently now, but I’m definitely a less is more kind of person. Some consider my approach too passive. I think people are comforted by frequent scans, tumor markers etc, because they feel as if their doctor, and by extension themselves, are doing “something”. However, if you evaluate the pros and cons of frequent scanning then each of us will arrive at what feels most comfortable to us. ** Disclosure: My bone met was discovered incidental to a scan unrelated to bc. You would think this would make me a supporter of frequent scanning, but no, I still don’t want the additional stress and radiation exposure

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 08:25PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi and Welcome, A PICC line ( peripherally inserted central catheter), is inserted, usually in the upper arm. A bit of the tubing sticks out from the skin. It is covered by a dressing when not in use. It must be cleaned and kept dry. There is a risk of infection. In the US, it is seldom used for chemo, as it's viewed as short term. For instance, people who need IV antibiotics for a couple of days-weeks, often get PICC lines. PICC line insertion is a very minor procedure. Ports are implanted under the skin in a longer surgical procedure, though it is still fairly quick and easy. Once the site has healed it requires no further care, other than flushing which is done after your infusion. Power ports also get a blood return so they can be used for blood draws. Ports can be left in for extended periods of time, years if needed. Please let me know if you need any other info. I have a Bard power port but have never had a PICC line. Also, come visit the stage IV forums. We are a great group ! Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2013 09:41AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Teacher911, Excellent news about NED! I am also glad that you stated that the goal of rads was to get rid of the bone mets. It is often said here that rads to bone mets is only done for pain management, but that is not the case in all instances. Rads can also render bone mets necrotic. This is not a systemic tx and doesn't prevent mets from cropping up elsewhere, but does reduce the tumor load. My RO and mo felt that since I had limited mets, actually just one, that this was a valuable tx. I think this represents part of the shift of thinking in how stage IV patients are treated. I hope this is a trend that continues as it is moving in the direction of treatment for chronic conditions. It is not a cure and not a solution for everyone but can certainly be effective for some. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2015 07:34PM exbrnxgrl wrote: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/121/topic... Here is a link to the matcha tea thread. I have been drinking matcha for almost30 years. I first had it in Japan at a tea ceremony and drank it because I liked it, not because of any health properties. So, what I know about matcha is related to drinking it for pleasure, not health, however it might help those who would like to actually enjoy it as they drink it. Matcha is not infused as most teas are. It is a finely ground powder that is whisked into the hot water. I use a chasen, traditional bamboo whisk, for my tea but am told that an immersion blender works too. Just stirring with a spoon doesn't quite work ,since the matcha doesn't dissolve. You want to whisk it until it's suspended in the water and drink it right away. The taste varies with quality. Buy the best quality you can afford, ceremonial if you can. Traditionally, matcha is not drunk in large quantities, so if you're making a big mug full and using a lot of matcha powder, it can be a pricey habit. I only drink about 1/3-1/2 cup at a time, but again, I don't do this therapeutically. The lower qualities taste "grassier" to me and are really made to be used in cooking (think matcha flavored ice cream, mochi, cakes etc. Anyway, I hope this helps with understanding qualities of matcha and how to prepare it. Really good matcha tastes much better than the cooking grade!

Best of all, we would walk to the candy store, which had a soda fountain, and order egg creams, a delicious sweet, frothy chocolate drink that contained neither eggs nor cream. Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 01:43AM exbrnxgrl wrote: You've been given lots of great tips. My port was put in at the same time I was having more surgery to my breast so I had a general. It was placed on my non-cancer side, in the hollow between my shoulder and chest. It is not visible unless I wear very thin straps and is not on the front of my chest. It is a Bard power port and looks like 3 raised dots arranged in a triangle. I use it for blood draws, which I schedule for two days before my infusions. Not only does an RN need to do it but one trained in the procedure and they must have the correct type of needle and heparin/saline to flush it. Because I schedule it in advance, I never run into the issue of the infusion nurses being too busy. As for PET scans, yes they can use the port but the same requirements as for a blood draw must be met. PET scan techs do not, as far as I know, have this training. I did have a major compliction after it was placed, a completely collapsed lung 2 weeks after placement , but that happens 1% of the time. Despite that horrendous episode, I love my power port. Good luck. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 09:26PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Kaiser Permanente is unusual, even in the world of HMO's. They have their own hospitals, labs, pharmacies, and every other medical facility/service you can imagine. Many of their facilities are huge campuses where everyone from the janitors to the most skilled doctors are all Kaiser employees. My campus offered several different types of reconstruction and I was free to go to any Kaiser facility and see any ps I chose. However, as far as I am aware, they almost never approve of anyone going outside their system unless it is truly a medical service they cannot reasonably provide. That would pretty much eliminate approval for going outside their system for reconstruction since they do offer it. As I mentioned ,their ps's only did reconstructive work until recently.My advice to the op would be to find a ps within their system who is willing and able to work with her. Mine was a gem.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2013 08:43PM exbrnxgrl wrote: The initial indication that bisphosphonates create an inhospitable climate for cancer has not panned out in long term studies and many oncs are moving away from this idea. They are beginning to limit bisphosphonate use, generally 24 months, due to ONJ and femur fracture risks, though both are rare. I had rads to my femur met. Pain relief was not the objective since I had no pain. Killing it was the one and only objective and it has been necrotic in the two years since I had rads. There really wasn't much of a process that went into making the decision. I had started Arimidex and consulted with the ro. He proposed 15 rounds of rads with that one goal in mind. It was very easy, other than having to drive there every day. No skin damage but I was scrupulous in applying aloe gel and Aquaphor. I had a tiny bit of diarrhea once a day after day 10, but it's hardly worth mentioning. Let me know if you have any other questions. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2013 11:36AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Having plan B is great advice. My plan A called for one step, no TE's, during a bmx. Plan B called for TE's if one step was not possible. To add to wide range of possibilities, I later had to have one nipple removed because the final path report showed a bit of DCIS too close to the nipple. Due to the fact that my ps only does reconstruction, he managed to be able to keep the one step implant in. However, he cautioned me before surgery, that this might not be possible and I might wake up with a TE (plan B). Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 09:18PM - edited Oct 7, 2013 02:18AM by exbrnxgrl Linda, I don't know if my advice is sage, but here it is. You know your family best and only you know how they would react if you told them. I can understand waiting until after the reunion, since you have no definitive information but depending on your relationship with them and how they've handled learning about your bc thus far, would they be more upset if you withheld information? I am very close to my dd's and although it has been painful for them to hear about my bc, and yes, they worry, they would be more upset if I kept anything from the. I raised them to be open and honest and to understand that family is there for you in good times or bad. Clearly, I have to live by what I taught them. But...this is me and my family dynamic. Only you know how your family dynamic goes. Don't just ask yourself what will happen if you tell them, but what will happen if you don't. Wishing you the best.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2016 08:09PM exbrnxgrl wrote: rufusdude, Things are a bit slow here on the weekend, but I'll answer as best as I can. I believe that you are referring to a titanium marker inserted at the time of biopsy. I have heard, rarely, that it can move from it's original placement to another area in the breast,however, I have never heard of it moving outside the breast. Breast cancer metastacizes by cancer cells moving through the lymph nodes or bloodstream, but not by a titanium marker carrying cells outside of the breast. Wishing you the best.

By somewhere else in your body, do you mean somewhere else in your breast? Cancer cells travel through the lymphatic system or bloodstream. What you are suggesting sounds like what is called seeding. Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 08:24AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I passed the 1 year mark in July. I was, for a few months, considered stage II, but my little bone met was probably there all along. In those few months I read enough on this forum to understand that stage IV was not a single disease nor a swift death sentence. So, although it sent my family into a tizzy I just focused on a treatment plan and getting my life back to as normal as possible. I have made an effort to get things in order (which is good for anyone to do). Didn't work over the summer. Did a lot of delayed house projects and garage cleaning. I also finally found the time to reflect on what bc has brought to me and what I want to do going forward. I don't want to stop working as it is my passion and a true calling and am lucky that I feel very good so I can. Basically, I want to carry on as if I didn't have bc because I know a day will come when I can't. And that's pretty much where I'm at right now. I have just decided I will live normally until I can't. I have made an odd peace with the fact that I know what I will die from this but don't dwell on it since no one knows when that will be. One of my colleagues was very teary eyed when she heard about my bc (I actually had to comfort her!). I looked at her and said, "I am not dying yet. Until then I will keep living." Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2014 06:08AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Denise, I just finished reading your blog post. Well written, my friend!  When my bone met was first discovered ( no pain or symptoms) I discussed tx with my primary and second opinion mo's. We spoke of the pros and cons of chemo vs. AI's.  Clearly, the chemo would have represented the possibility of curative intent. But, 1-2% are cured? That isn't even statistically significant in my mind. That wasn't enough to justify the possible decrease in QOL if the overwhelming odds were against it working as a cure anyway. Both mo's thought either choice that I made would be reasonable. I went with the AI's and have been NED for 3 years. I also had radiation to my bone met. I have not had an AI fail but I did switch a few months ago due to increased se's from my original AI. Additionally, when I exhaust the AI's there have been some studies that indicate chemo having a better effect on a body that is chemo naive. My life has been, essentially, normal. Work, family, travel etc. continue to give me great joy and fulfillment. Currently, stage IV is incurable because, as I said, 1-2% cure rate is more an anomaly than anything else, particularly when it's not understood how that cure is even achieved. I would look at a doctor who told me stage IV was curable, like he was crazy. It would be like saying I was a successful teacher but only 1-2% of my students had learned to read. I don't know if there will be a cure in my lifetime, though I hope so. I can handle chronic and never ending tx as long as I have a good QOL. Although I think about bc everyday, it doesn't consume me. I won't let bc rob me of a minute of my life until it absolutely has to and living as best as I can despite stage IV is how I cope. I can't use the idea of possible cure as something to hang my hat on because it doesn't seem close enough, but chronic is good enough for now. Take good care of yourself. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 09:27AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Don't really want to get into this but the 50/50 thing is not a statistical reality. Yes, bc can be unpredictable and we can't say with certainty who will recur or who who won't but history shows us that if you fit certain parameters you chances of recurrence my vary. Are these stats absolute? No, some who have a low chance of recurrence will recur and some who have a high chance won't. If you applied the 50/50 model to everyday life you can see why it's not accurate i.e. 50% chance of being in a car accident every time you drive, 50% chance of getting food poisoning every time you eat etc. Barbe, I know you believe this and I agree that there seems to be no rhyme or reason behind some recurrences, but it's just not a statistical reality. Individuals are, of course, not statistics. Statistics give us a general picture of what is more or less likely to happen given a certain set of factors. Are there anomalies and deviations? Yes, but that doesn't render it all down to 50/50. Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 08:22PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I had to take an online class to learn about BRCA testing as part of the process to determine if it would be appropriate for me. It was emphasized that you get half your genes from your mother and half from your father and since bc is not a gender specific disease, your father's family medical history is important. What is more important is to remember is that with what is currently known, not all cancers are linked to BRCA when one is looking at hereditary factors. For example your family can have a long history of uterine cancer but that would not be linked to BRCA but ovarian cancer would be. Ethnicity can play a role as well and for those family members with bc, age of disease onset is relevant. Good luck to you. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 05:48PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Nope, don't agree with that at all. Statistics do not provide individual guarantees on recurrence, nor are they absolute. There are always deviations and anomalies, but it doesn't boil down to 50/50. Statistics cannot predict with absolute certainty how you, as an individual, will do and shouldn't be interpreted as such. A good example is lung puncture during port insertion. Statistics say there is a 1% chance of this happening when performed by an experienced surgeon. Well, it happened to me! Still, I would never tell anyone that the chances were 50/50 but I would agree with the crapshoot comment since there was no way of predicting ahead of time that I would be part of this unlucky, tiny minority. Wish I had won the lottery instead! Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 10:16AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi LK, I feel your pain and I know things look bleak right now. The initial part of the journey is so hard and it sometimes feels impossible to keep the mind from going to the darkest places. I am stage IV. I won't go into every little detail (you can search my screen name and read my posts) but I had some rough months including a rare complication from port insertion. I am not the same, physically or emotionally, as before dx but remarkably, I am not that different. It took a while to get here, but with the help of a great medical team, Effexor and assorted other drugs as needed, my life is pretty normal. I have gained a bit of weight from meds, my boobs are silicone and my joints a bit achy BUT I work full time at a job I adore(1st grade teacher), became a grandmother, am planning younger dd's wedding and a cruise to New Zealand and Australia. Having stage IV is not what I envisioned and I know that someday it will get worse but it's not today! Please find a psychiatrist who has experience with cancer patients and take meds if appropriate. No shame and it may make a world of difference. You don't have to be positive and perky all the time but don't put your foot in the grave yet. Yes, some stage IV women are struggling and will lose the battle but many of us have years of good life to live and so do you. Please pm me for any support you need. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2016 09:30AM exbrnxgrl wrote: divine, Your question is a good one but I suspect those stats might not exist. How many people have mets from the start but don't know it? At this point in time, we have no way of knowing. Speculating, based on those who post on bco, is of limited value for me because message boards represent only a small sampling of those with bc. I know it seems like there are a lot of us, but people who post on message boards are not a valid sampling for statisical purposes. Barbe, I'm sure I was one who quibbled with your 100% or 0% statement. Survival stats are not a predictor of how an individual will do, and should never be interpreted as such. They are based on historical data and have no individual predictive value. It's baffles me when people get upset if they fall outside a positive looking stat. Yes, you may have a 90% survival rate if you do treatment xyz, and that's quite good. But someone will fall into the 10% that doesn't survive, and sadly, it may any one of us. Many of you know that I experienced a collapsed lung after port installation. The statistical incidence of that is 1%. My chance was 1% just like everyone else, however my reality was that I fell into that 1%. That doesn't change the overall odds, because they never predict individual outcomes. Statistics don't tell the stories of individuals. I understand and accept their limitations and never, ever mistake them for anything more. I am sitting in the Denver airport dealing with a 2 hour flight delay due to high winds in San Francisco. Wonder what the chances of that were? 😉

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 02:02PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi martygra, I had my SNB during my bmx so I don't know what type of anesthesia you will get. Call your docs office right now and ask them to explain, in detail, exactly how SNB will happen including anesthesia, after care etc. These are the kinds of things you need to ask before every procedure, test etc. Taking control will go a long way toward alleviating your anxiety. You are just as much a member of your care team as any doctor. As a matter of fact, you are the team leader! Go out and buy an expanding file and use it to file and save everything relating to your bc especially test results and path reports. Again, taking charge will not only give you a greater sense of control, but will give you something positive to do.I also want to confirm that IDC is invasive and the I can stand for invasive or infiltrating. Bc is not welcome news for anyone but it is your situation to take charge of so you don't let it victimize you. Lots of good thoughts and prayers for you. Caryn

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: Ok, it was really oncology wellness massage, but all I could say afterwards was ahhhh! A beautiful day spa offered this service and I had a gift card so I finally went. When I made the appointment they carefully picked the therapist as only some are trained for this service. I had to fill out a comprehensive questionnaire about my cancer, including info on lymph node removal and lymphedema. The massage therapist reviewed it and asked me additional questions. She even provided a a rolled up sheet to put under my foobs so laying on my stomach was comfortable. After the massage, I took a lovely shower with beautiful bath products. I felt so relaxed it should have been illegal to drive home. If you find a place in your area that is experienced in oncology massage you should give it a try. It was wonderful medicine. Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi All, Well, I'm a bit ashamed to tell this tale as I probably should have known better but here goes. We had a baby shower for my older daughter yesterday. As you can imagine I am thrilled beyond words to be expecting my first grandchild, a little girl. I was never much of a drinker but did imbibe on special occasions but stopped even that since being diagnosed. Anyway, I had, perhaps, a half glass of champagne and a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon. I woke up this morning with what felt like the worst hangover ever. Tried to eat a bit of dry toast and sip water but felt awful. Went back to bed and woke up at 1:15pm !!! As the day went on I felt better but am now thinking that even a small amount of alcohol doesn't mix well with meds. I take Arimidex, Effexor, Claritan and 1 Ativan nightly. Any thoughts? Humbly, Caryn Bilateral mx 9/7/11 with one step ns reconstruction. Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2013 10:46PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I have been very open about having a bmx and my treatment.I always say I have  bc and will always be in tx but I have not told many people,specifically, that I am stage IV.  Why? Well, laziness I guess. I just didn't have the patience to explain the whole thing to people who were not in my inner circle. My school district and the staff at my site have been great but I didn't feel there was any reason for them to know. I do my job as I always have. All of my family knows as do close friends. My daughters (22 and 28) feel comfortable with the choice I've made and don't feel as if they are keeping a secret. When people ask how I am, and they say fine, they are not lying since I am doing very well. Not telling the nitty gritty details is not a lie, in my opinion. If someone were to press me or my dd's for details, I would have no problem with telling. However, you and your son need to talk about it and come to some sort of an agreement. Ultimately, I think it's your call since you are the one with bc!

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2018 07:26AM exbrnxgrl wrote: l love my port! Mine never bothered me at all and was placed in the little hollow between shoulder and chest so it is not visible. Please note that not all places provide EMLA, numbing cream mentioned above as it’s pricey, but almost all offer a short acting numbing spray. Port-a-cath is a brand name, the general name is just port. It provides a quick, easy and painless way to access your vein and if it’s a power port can be used for blood draws as well (ask about that). Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Chemo Port-O-Caths: Did you get one? What was is like? buttercup1 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: May 19, 2018 11:24PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Yes, the Bard Power Ports are famous for their purple color. I have the small one and am thin, but since it was placed in the little hollow where my shoulder meets my upper chest, it doesn't stick out and is not visible when i'm dressed. Meg101, Most people have no issues with their ports. I myself had the rarest of complications, a collapsed lung, but realize that while possible, it's highly unlikely. I would still recommend a port. PICC lines are less commonly used in the US due to the fact that they are "open" and involve restrictions on getting wet. You do see them for shorter term use, i.e. antibiotics that must be given intravenously for a few weeks. Once you have healed from the port installation, for most people a short easy process, the port is care free. Do some folks have problems? Of course, but they are in the minority (and I was one of them!). Let's not forget that Power Ports also allow for blood draws and nuclear injections if you get PET scans.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2014 09:21AM exbrnxgrl wrote: musiclover, Many of our bco sisters, myself included, will testify to the fact that dark chocolate is a miracle drug. Indulge as often as needed :)  All kidding aside, I'm going to say what I've been skirting around for a while and I apologize in advance if I upset or offend you. Whether you wanted them or not, you will not be getting any more cancer free years. However, it is quite likely that you will still be getting quite a few years or maybe even more than that. Yes, you will be receiving some type of tx forever, but you can have a life that is fulfilling and happy. Perhaps, not the life you planned, but you get to decide what to do with the life you've been given. I don't think I am particularly strong, and certainly not brave, I'm just doing the best I can under imperfect circumstances. Personally, I don't believe there is a miracle cure. Lots of good stories but no miracles that have been proven. I will try to be as healthy as possible, but I will enjoy food and drink as it pleases me. I will not spend my time choking down stuff that doesn't give me pleasure or allow me the splendid social opportunities of shared meals, nor will I spend excessive amounts of time preparing food for restrictive diets. The only place coffee will enter my body is through my mouth! Now, here's the big one...I will not allow depression or obsession over finding a miracle steal my time and enjoyment of life. I know you are not keen on therapy/psychs or meds, but they can lift the veil of darkness, whether you live for only one year or fifty. I will not ask you why you are so opposed to this (psych/meds) as I'm sure you have your reasons but know, that many of us have availed ourselves of this and it 's made a world of difference. It does not dull you or make you zombie like. You sound very depressed and that's not any way to live, bc or not. Just my thoughts and I apologize in advance if I upset you. Fondly, Caryn

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 02:41PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I understand the temptation to bury your head in the sand. But as the shock wears off, you will feel more in control and empowered if you become a knowledgable part of your treatment team. Yes, you! No medical degree needed to contribute and fully participate in medical decisions but you must be fully informed to do this. I love my doctors and have chosen them carefully ( got rid of my first mo) so they deal with me as an intelligent, deliberate patient. This is your body and your life and I feel quite strongly that you just can't cede all decision making power over to the docs. Bringing someone with you who can take notes and ask questions is very helpful especially in the beginning when emotions run high. I wish you all the best. Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2012 01:35PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Spamgirl, Kids have such limited life experience. When something new crops up, like bc, they really have no framework for understanding so they fit it into what the do know. Sickness, to them is a cold or a tummy ache. They know that germs for these illnesses can be passed around, so that's the only perspective they have on illness. I am an elementary school teacher and a mom. I have seen kids come to all kinds of interesting conclusions on illness, death, divorce etc. It's endlessly fascinating, sometimes funny, sometimes sad. That's why telling them the truth, in an age appropriate way, is so important. Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2015 11:33PM - edited Aug 8, 2015 11:34PM by exbrnxgrl What bestbird describes sounds like a sensible diet that most can live with. I think it's also important to thoroughly enjoy the not so healthy stuff once in a while and feel absolutely no guilt about it. I figure the guilt may be more harmful than the food you ate, and the pleasure you derived from eating it can only help. I was at a party in a bar last night. The bar is know for it's hand crafted drinks made with local, organic ingredients (California is a funny place!). I enjoyed a delicious gin, cucumber and St. Germain cocktail and split a hand thrown arugula Parmesan pizza with a friend. I savored each sip and bite, chatted with lots of people and went home feeling happy and stress free. That is very healthy in my book! On a more serious note, as many of us have often written, overall healthy eating and lifestyle is good for all. Do the best you can, make healthy changes that you can live with and don't stress over either a restrictive diet or small lapses in a reasonable one.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2015 12:09PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Alas, we are banned from all shellfish! The Torah simply says it is unclean. The mixing of meat and dairy goes back to a Caananite practice of cooking goat in it's mother's milk, which was viewed as cruel. Again, the injunction in the Torah is ,just don't do it. Many, many rabbis over the ensuing centuries have given explanations as to why. Check out this link. http://www.aish.com/atr/Why_Not_Milk__Meat.html?ta... Please remember that kosher laws also prohibit the mixing of utensils, cookware, serving ware, including dishes, bowls etc., from being "crossed". A true kosher home will have two sets of everything; one for fleish (meat) and one for milch (dairy). Those who can afford it will even have separate ovens, sinks, etc Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 11:09PM exbrnxgrl wrote: What great mothers you all are. Children, even very young ones, have a kind of sixth sense and will always know when something is up. They will think of all kinds of crazy stuff and sometimes even think they were the cause of mommy being sick, in lieu of the truth. I had a child in my class once who started complaining of bad stomaches every day and always wanted to go home. It got so bad that he was missing large chunks of academic instruction. Finally met with his mom and she mentioned that she and her husband were divorcing but didn't want to tell the kids. She told the kids dad was on a business trip! With the help of the school psychologist, we found a support group for the kids, age appropriate books and of course, mom and dad told the kids. Clearly, the child knew something was up and it manifested itself as stomaches at school. Not the same as cancer, but you get the idea. Tiffany, even though my dd's are in their 20's, it was still weird to have them worrying and taking care of me. They are still my children and I'm still mom! Caryn

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: As some of you know, I have a single 2cm met to my femur head. My tx has been Anastrozole, rads x15 to the femur met and monthly Aredia. I feel great, work out 5-6 days a week, cleaned up an already decent diet, juice and take D3, glucosimine/chondroitin. I am also on Effexor and Ativan.Went back to work 5 weeks ago and am thrilled to be back. I have gone to Stanford, twice, for second opinions. My Stanford MO and my Kaiser MO know each other and consult easily. The Stanford MO brought up the possibility of doing chemo with curative intent. This is based on a 1996 study of women with limited metastaic bc. The study involved 1,581 subjects of different ages, menopausal status, ER status and area of mets. A small percentage of the subjects, across the board, achieved complete remission. I am currently wading through the study to pick out what percentage of those women most closely resemble me. My Kaiser MO said she would be willing to give it a go, using ACT, but it was up to me. She said and Stanford doc agrees, that there is no clear " right" choice. So, do I continue along a tx path that regards my disease as a chronic condition or do I gamble, with poor odds, on going for an initially harsher tx that may, or may not, pay off in the long run. I have a PET scheduled for next Weds. but my MO doesn't think it will provide ant major info to factor into my decision, unless I've had progression, which she doubts. I really value all input especially stage IV sisters since you all understand the emotional component of this. My gut, BTW, says to stay the course and not do chemo right now but this is definitely crazy making. Caryn Bilateral mx 9/7/11 with one step ns reconstruction. As of 11/21/11, 2cm met to upper left femur Dx 7/8/2011, IDC, Left, 4cm, Grade 1, 1/15 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/7/2011 Lymph node removal: Left; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Dx 11/2011, IDC, Left, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 1, 1/15 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 11/21/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Radiation Therapy 11/21/2011 Bone Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2014 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2016 10:41AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Titanium is routinely used in joint replacements and other medical devices, so no, it is not in the same category as leaking silicone.Very, very few people have a reaction to titanium, but that doesn't mean that no one does. I am so sorry that you fell in to that minority. I think the nurse framed her response badly. The marker, which is about the size of a grain of rice, marks the area of biopsy . Yes, it is convenient for the doctors, should you need another biopsy, but as a patient, it gives you some ease knowing that the exact area of concern is marked and easily found if there are any questions down the road. Should you ever need another biopsy, your previous allergic reaction to titanium will clearly make using another marker out of the question. Again, I am so sorry that this happened to you, but it is a very rare situation. I wish things could be foolproof when it come to medical tx, but that's not our reality. BTW, I had an adverse event when my port was put in. Something that only happens 1% of the time. It resulted in a rush to the ER, a week in hospital and a month at home with a portable chest tube. I hated that I fell in to that tiny minority, but I understand that it happens, rarely, but it does. Feel better soon.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2014 04:41PM exbrnxgrl wrote: musiclover, I think a big part of my calm is just who I am by nature and the fact that I learned long ago not to worry too much about things I can't change. This is not to say I do nothing about my bc, but beyond doing what I'm comfortable with, I let the rest go. I know bc will rob me of tomorrow, someday, but I refuse to let it rob me of today. I eat reasonably and don't fret about a cookie if I want one. I don't spend time on restrictive diets. I do take some supplements but do so for overall health, not because I think it will cure me. I am 57 and have had a good life. I have a job I love, two fabulous daughters and a sweet granddaughter. I have traveled extensively, and still do when the bank acct. allows. Of course, I have had the usual ups and downs (23 years of a crappy marriage), just lost my mother, lost my younger sister 3 years ago etc. I don't want to die any sooner than I have to, but I am at peace with my life. Yes, I did see a psych. My HMO refers cancer patients to a guy who specializes in those with cancer. I liked talking with him and I have been on Effexor since the beginning of this weird trip. I still feel totally like me and see no reason not to take it. Fear? Fear can be crippling and would rob me of the here and now. Musiclover, your dx is still relatively new but if your fear is taking away from your QOL, talking to someone might help, even without meds. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2013 09:15AM exbrnxgrl wrote: It would be wonderful if we could pin the cause of bc to one thing, be it diet, stress or heredity. The reality is we can't. While keeping stress to a minimum and maintaining a healthy lifestyle are advisable for all of us, failing to do this does not cause bc. As for heredity, the vast majority of bc arises without a known genetic connection. Very, very few people have the BRCA 1 or 2 gene ( there are probably other mutations, but they are not known yet). There simply is no direct cause and effect known at this time. Focus on what you can do now to stay as healthy as possible. Wishing you the best. Caryn

I have never had chemo, simply AI's. My lifestyle and diet are geared toward the healthy, but I am not compulsive about it and treat myself to whatever strikes my fancy, without guilt or worry. In a nutshell, I don't do anything to actively fight my MBC (other than take my letrozole every night). Jenn is not the only person to go off of Herceptin and thrive. So, while Jenn and I are exceptional responders, I think we don't yet know why.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 11:48PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I certainly think everyone has an absolute right to decide how much of a participant they want to be in their own treatment. I belong to a self contained HMO ( they have large campuses with hospital, medical offices, pharmacies, labs etc. in one place as well as some smaller satellite offices). A cornerstone of their healthcare philosophy is a proactive patient/doctor relationship coupled with a strong emphasis on wellness. They want you to be an active part of the treatment and strongly encourage you to be fully informed. Of course,I am sure they treat folks who don't want to know or be active in tx decisions. This makes me think of my mom who was having severe back pain recently. She saw her doctor who gave her an injection in her back. "What was it?" , I asked. "I don't know but I feel better" , she said. I can't even imagine not knowing but if it worked for her, who am I to argue? Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2018 10:43PM - edited Apr 17, 2018 11:03PM by exbrnxgrl Leesa, I am so sorry that you had that experience and hope you continue to recover . While not common, port infections can happen and that is a known possibility (infection rates with PICC lines are higher than with ports). In the spirit of full disclosure, I had the ultimate rare port complication happen; a collapsed lung. it's a long story but suffice to say not a pretty one. Still, it is so rare that I would never recommend against a port. Anytime you insert a foreign object in your body there is some risk, no matter how small. But I don't want my story to cause women worry or decide not to get ports. I just fell into the unlucky 1% who have this complication.If you're looking for a medical procedure with 0% risk, it's unlikely you'll find any. The vast majority have ports inserted, used and removed without complications.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 10:56AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I don't know about the technical aspects of testing the blood sample, i.e. if it is simple, but how do you verify the credibility of this lab? The test is proprietary thus far ,so I'm not sure that another lab can guarantee that they are testing for the same things that Myriad is testing for. Even if you could verify the fidelity of the test, you raise a good point when asking about genetic counseling. Here is what my genetic counselor and genetic psychologist did for me: - determined if I fell into a group at risk for BRCA mutations - set me up with an online class on BRCA mutations that explained what they were/were not and helped me understand what questions and options would need to be explored if I tested positive. Also, explained the implications for family members - provided post-test support and explained the lengthy results data from Myriad I really appreciated the information and support. I had read and heard quite a few things that turned out not to be true, so the education alone was worth it. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2011 03:46AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I won't pretend to know a lot about the oncotype test but my thinking has been along the same lines as MaryNY. Grade/aggressiveness is but one aspect of the tumor. In and of itself, it may not be the only factor in determining the potential effectiveness of chemo. Other tumor characteristics may play a role in the efficacy of chemo. I think that this is quite an advance in that tumors are being analyzed for their particular characteristics rather just grade/size which seems somewhat limiting. TN's do not respond to hormonals as others have stated, so oncotype, which assumes use of hormonals currently has no value for them. Very interesting discussion! Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 06:27AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Lymphedema is a funny thing. Very little is known in terms of predicting who will or won't get it. If you've had an AND your chances are greater than for those with only SNB. My pt also said research indicates that those who are overweight have a higher chance of developing it. That being said, anyone with node removal is at risk even years after the surgery. Read about LE on the main bco site. I also believe that they referenced an article showing higher rates of truncal LE in SNB patients. My pt taught me lymph drainage massage in addition to the prevention tips. Caryn
Posts.Title: Any October 2011 Surgeries out there want to wait together? gamergirl GrandmaV

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 08:54AM exbrnxgrl wrote: SNB is sentinel node biopsy, AND is axillary node dissection. You can take steps to try to prevent it but as my pt said, and almost everything you read will confirm, there is no way to predict who will or won't get it. Taking preventative measures is helpful but it's still a crap shoot. Caryn
