Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2012 04:19PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Most of you know I don't get upset or offended by people's comments, adverts, or the color pink. I'm quite easy going about most things. However an acquaintance from my flight attendant days posted something on FB that raised my hackles. Additionally, I was stupid enough to continue arguing with her. She posted a link to natural news, an article by Mike Adams( the health ranger) calling mammograms a medical hoax. Additionally she spouted some barely informed info about how doctors are urging women to cut their breasts off because of "some gene". I challenged her on this, acknowledging that mammos are not perfect and that some doctors order the BRCA test without genetic counseling, but overall the medical profession has many, many caring and competent practitioners. She came back with some story about aspartame and macular degeneration and a story about a chef who cured herself with diet alone. When I asked if the chef could share this diet with others, so it could be replicated and studied there was no reply. When I asked if those who are big pharma get cancer or if their loved ones get cancer, no reply. Here is the kicker, she has no health insurance so gets no medical care or screenings. She surmises that perhaps this is why she is so healthy! i.e. traditional medicine has not "found" a disease to cure in her with their treatments and meds that do more harm than good. There was also a lot about what she has read over the years about breast cancer and other aspects of traditional medicine. Really? Really? You are saying this to a stage IV bc patient who has, not voluntarily, become all too well informed about bc. Sheesh! Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 05:46AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Another happy port owner here! I have a petite Bard power port. This model is great as it is small, thin and barely visible. Mine is placed in the little hollow where my shoulder meets my chest. It is not visible at all unless I wear spaghetti straps, but I don't! I can easily wear tank tops, deep scoop necks, v- necks etc. I use it not only for infusions, but PET scans and all blood draws. I have no problem, and it takes no time, to have my blood drawn at the infusion center ( they send it to the lab). Yes, you can leave it in indefinitely if you have it flushed every 4-6 weeks. Since we are all stage IV, I figure we probably have very good reason to leave it in, and certainly a good reason to get one. It really is my very good friend. I do have EMLA cream but my center uses a very effective numbing spray so I just go with that. Good luck with your decision. Caryn P.S. I am the 1% who had a lung puncture at port insertion. Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 05:18PM exbrnxgrl wrote: pocket, I am very sorry that this happened to you. It sounds like a dreadful ordeal. I don't know how many attorneys you have consulted, but if if several feel that you don't have a case, then all of this may fall into the category of the risk we all assume with medical procedures and the side effects and risks that occur with them. Malpractice and/or negligence are very different from that. For instance, when a port is installed, there is a 1% chance of lung puncture. An x-ray is taken after the procedure to verify that this has not happened. I had all of this done but two weeks after the procedure, it was discovered that I had a complete collapse of one lung. How did this happen? Well, my lung was nicked and it created something like a slow leak on a tire. It was not visible on the post procedure x-ray. Fixing it involved a wild dash to the ER, the painful insertion of a chest tube, 6 days in the hospital with two more chest tube insertions and another month at home with a portable chest tube. Horrible as it was, these were all possible risks of port installation. No one to really blame. However, I do hope you have written letters of complaint to all of the doctors and facilities involved. Take care.

Posts.Title: thoughts about difference between remission and NED reader123 leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 10:33AM - edited Jan 12, 2014 10:34AM by exbrnxgrl good discussion. My mo does use the term NED and I have a single bone met. Yes, it still shows up on PET scans but is not active. As for stage at initial dx, that is based on info available at the time. In my case, after my bmx, I was staged IIb. Less than 6 weeks later, before I even had a chance to begin chemo, my bone met was found through an unrelated test. No pain, no symptoms. Had it not been for that unrelated scan, we would have believed I was IIb until I became symptomatic. So, I believe I was stage IV from the start but if the met hadn't been accidentally found we would have happily assumed I was IIb until some future time. Would I have then said I was IIb for xx years until I had bone met symptoms?  I think my point is that NED is a general term which simply means no current evidence of disease but means little in terms of how much or how little time when stays that way or whether one looks at a period after a lower stage dx as anything meaningful. It simply refers to your current state. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2012 04:19AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Linda, Good to "see" you here! I think you're asking the million dollar question. No one knows, time wise, the rate of progression. Also bear in mind that progression does not accelerate numerically through each stage, although by stage III there's only one way to go. I was IIB after surgery and less than 3 months later, stage IV. Never saw stage III but suspect my bone met was there all along and if you remember my story, discovered by accident. No pain or any other symptoms. I have been fortunate in that I have tolerated Arimidex, Aredia and rads to my bone met very well. Love my one step implants too and have carried on with my life very normally save for too many medical appointments. Recently released from pt since my frozen shoulder has almost completely disappeared and my last PET was clear so I get a 6 month pass from seeing my mo. I know it's not easy but try not to focus on the possibility of progression. Treat yourself well and enjoy each day. I know my good run won't last forever but I plan to enjoy it while I can. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 06:38PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Gamergirl, I have been a life long needle phobe. People have reported various experiences with the SNB injections. Some places include a bit of lidocaine in the injection, others don't. I have one word for you, EMLA. This a very strong topical anesthetic available by presscription only. I think the generic is available too as lidocaine/prilocaine. It must be applied about 1 hour before the procedure and covered with an occlusive dressing. I have written about it on a few other threads as I have used it over the years for several procedure involving needle sticks. I am a huge fan and no, I don't work for the manufacturer :) Best wishes for an easy recovery. Caryn

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 12:14AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Just yesterday, I read this thread with interest and trepidation as I waited for results of a biopsy I had last week. My story is short but complicated; diagnosed 7/8/11 stage 2B IDC and DCIS in left breast. NS BMX ( rt prophy) on 9/7/11 . 1 positive node. Second surgery on 10/13/11 to remove spared nipple due to more DCIS. Port installed at same time. Two weeks later, PET scan finds collapsed right lung thought to be result of tiny nick during port installation which resulted in what was essentially a slow leak. Rush to ER, had 3 chest tubes inserted and spent 6 days in hospital. PET also spot on hip so had MRI which let to biopsy. Onc called today to say it is a 2 cm met. Immediately starting Arimidex and will see RO tomorrow. Chest tube is still in and should come out Weds. I am still in shock. Prior to original diagnosis I felt fine. I can't even begin to understand how any of this happened. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 10:45PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Nettie, As others have said, a biopsy and imaging suggest preliminary staging. Final staging is done on tissue removed either during mastectomy or lumpectomy. These results can differ from the results of the biopsy. There is no blood or other test that determines final,staging. I would also consider getting a second opinion as this can help confirm/clarify what is already known. Best of luck to you

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 05:04AM exbrnxgrl wrote: If you believe everything happens for a reason, this is a good story to support that. I had a bmx with one step, ns/ss reconstruction. Final path report showed dcis too close to one nipple and 1 positive node. Scheduled surgery to have nipple removed and port installed simultaneously. During recovery mo wanted to enroll me in phase III clinical trial. This required echo cardiogram. Some fluid found around my heart so PET was ordered. PET discovers completely collapsed right lung thought to be as a result of tiny nick during port placement which caused a slow leak. Rushed to ER, hospitalized for 6 days. MO also notes PET found spot on upper femur. MRI done but inconclusive. After healing from lung issue, I had a bone biopsy. Bingo! 2 cm bone met. No pain, no symptoms. Soooo, if I had never had the echo which led to the PET the bone met might not have been found until it became symptomic and possibly more widespread. Not to mention the collapsed lung which presented with atypical symptoms. Things have gone much more smoothly since then. Last PET was clear and I went back to work in Jan. of this year. I'm a teacher so am currently enjoying summer vacation, but am looking forward to a new school year in late August. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 12:15PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Chrys23, So sorry that this has been a tough road. You may rant all you want!! I try not to criticize other posts but I would like to say something to those who have had an easy time with surgery, chemo, rads etc. I am glad it was easy for you. I am glad that your facility pampered you. In am glad that your positive attitude and maintaining a normal life made this easy for you. But please bear in mind that for some, all of these things will not help to mitigate side effects and bad reactions. It is simply not possible to control all of these things! We are all very different and despite the efforts we make and our medical teams make, some will have a tough time. Yes, we should all make an effort, as should our docs an nurses, to curb se's but let's not imply that this is always possible if only we do the "right" things. My love and prayers to those who are struggling and cheers to those who are having an easier time as well. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 09:19PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Yes, this is an interesting discussion. I guess I always viewed gender as whether you identified as male or female. The original designation is based on your genitalia, at birth, but as we know, people don't always feel that they match the gender of their genitals. When one loses a physical part that identified with a specific gender, i.e. Breasts on a women, does that change ones gender identity? For many, I would guess no, since one would have many years to identify as a woman and still feel like one despite the loss of breasts. For others that might not be true and I'm sure many of us have wrestled with how it effects our own image of what femininity is. Sexuality has to do with having sexual feelings.Whether we act on those feelings with members of the opposite gender, same gender, with our own hands or not at all is how that sexuality manifests itself. BC and all that is done to us in order to stave it off can clearly effect both gender identification and sexuality. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2019 12:35PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi parry and happy New Year. First, I want to say that we are all very different in terms of our physical ability to travel. Not every stage IV is out conquering the world! Talk to your mo about your desire to travel so you can find out what accommodations can be made in terms of your tx Start small; A long weekend perhaps? In the US you can get travel insurance that covers pre-existing conditions. I have used a Travel Guard in the past. Wherever you go, plan to take it easy and build some rest time into each day. If you feel up to it, you can always add more activities. I don’t know what your immediate medical needs may be, but I wasn’t too concerned about knowing where hospitals and doctors were. I had gotten cleared to travel by my mo, so I just worked on the premise that any medical emergencies that might crop up would be handled like a medical emergency that anyone could have when traveling. I have traveled quite a bit since my stage IV dx, both domestically and internationally. Happy to answer any questions you might have!

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2016 12:02PM - edited Feb 7, 2016 12:15PM by exbrnxgrl longtermsurvivor, I agree that none of us is a statistical average, nor do statistics tell any one person's story. However, in making informed treatment decisions, data does provide a rational jumping off point for me and many others. I realize that scientific data and research are not important to some. Of course no one can say that they have followed proven tx, conventional, and that they have received all the benefits. None of the conventional treatments promise anything but you know that going in to it. If treatment XYZ has data that says 75% of those who follow it will be cured, you have to understand that 25% won't be. Additionally, you have no way of knowing which side you will fall on, but at least you know that when you are in the decision making process. I'd like to see the same for alt tx. Just the way my brain works 😊. I need double blind, randomized, replicable data. I'm an academic through and through (by nature and profession).  Lily, I'm going to try to read the Moss report again. I tried to read it late at night, which never works for me.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 01:57AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Gender , or at least how one identifies, is on a continuum for some people. Many of us have traits that are often attributed, if we are women, to the male gender and vice a versa. Sexuality is a whole other issue. As for me, I went through menopause naturally at age 52. I still felt very feminine and maintained my sexuality. At age 55, I had a bmx with one step reconstruction and shortly after that a bone met was found and I went on Arimidex. My foobs are very real looking, warm and firm but not in an unyielding way. I still feel completely like a woman and though I currently have no man in my life,but feel that my sexuality is intact. I have always loved being woman but am not a slave to stereotypes or societal expectations. I wear makeup and dress well because I want to and if I want to wear sweats and no make up somedays, I do that too. BC has been rough and though it may eventually, it has not robbed me of my femininty or my sunny, upbeat nature, even at stage IV. Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2014 02:03PM - edited Feb 16, 2014 02:03PM by exbrnxgrl musiclover, We all ask ourselves many questions about our bc and it's tx. I am somewhat less concerned about how/why I got bc, as it's water under the bridge for me. The only value , if the answer were known, might be in helping others. I hope you will forgive my frankness here and this, of course is simply my opinion: "The Secret",  thinking only good thoughts will cure us or get us what we want? Magical thinking of the highest order. Bruce Lipton; we assume our parents diseases by thinking we will get them? That's some major bs. If we say we don't want something, we will get it? This is so absurd to me that I can't even comment. Our bc is not due to mistakes we made or things we did "wrong". I think it is more likely the perfect storm of many factors. I believe I did nothing "wrong" and have never once blamed myself or tried to pinpoint what exactly caused my bc. As for G-d, since beliefs in G-d vary widely and since those who are atheists as well as devout believers get bc, I'm leaving that out of the equation. As for children getting cancer, whether one believes in G-d or not, no one was promised a perfect life and sadly, that includes children.  Musiclover, I'm not knocking your beliefs or search for answers, simply expressing my own on the subject. I am 2 1/2 years out from my stage IV dx and by choice, as well as personality, live each day as normally and happily as possible. For me, all that worry about perfect diet, why I got cancer, positive attitude etc. would be emotionally draining, energy wasting and suck the joy out of whatever time I have left. I hope you find peace and spend your time doing what brings happiness. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 11:01AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Heather, What I take away from all of this, as well as almost everything else having to do with every aspect of bc, is that it is as much a matter of opinion, by each medical practitioner, as it is a science. Also, what we post on these boards is not the same as the detailed clinical info our docs are seeing. So although it may sound like we are similar there are probably myriad variations that our docs take in to account. Short of gross negligence,most docs are doing what they think will work best for the patient. As long as we stay informed, question things and try to fit all the pieces of the puzzle together , we are doing all we can. Caryn

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 09:59PM exbrnxgrl wrote: This is such a great topic with as many twists and turns as a good thriller. Yes, the science is out there but sometimes it's limited and sometimes conflicting. I have, as far as I know, one bone met (PET tomorrow so who knows what will turn up). I have never done chemo, just rads to the met, Arimidex and Aredia. My mo, after talking to me about oligometastasis (limited mets) said I could do chemo if I wanted. The studies on chemo and oligomets are limited and ther is still controversy over whether such a state actually exists. I decided to stay the course and not do chemo for now but would consider it when I have progression. It has been a little over a year since my dx and after my bmx and pneumothorax recovery, it has been a good year. I went back to work at a job I love and became a grandmother while feeling great almost all the time. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 06:44PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Jillian, I'll offer a big hug as well. I had a bmx and was staged as IIB. Final path showed cancer too close to one nipple so I had that removed and a port inserted at the same time, about 6 weeks after bmx(with one step implants). Had unrelated PET scan two weeks later which revealed 1) complete pneumothorax of right lung, probably due to puncture duringport insertion 2) suspicious spot on femur. After I recovered from collapsed lung, biopsy confirmed spot on femur was a met from bc. Had rads to the femur, now necrotic, and have been on Arimidex and Aredia since then. So, I too went from early stage to stage IV in 4 months. Of course, the femur met may have been there all along but no reason to suspect it. I was, fortunately, in good health and am doing well 15 months later. If the Arimidex se's are bad, can you try another AI? As for doctors, is it possible to find coordinated care at a comprehensive cancer center? I think having confidence in your doctors and having them function as a team is very important especially with your other medical issues. Wishing you the best. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 07:00AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi ckachoo, Sorry that you've had to join us but welcome. Let me start by saying I have no experience with chemo. I am on Arimidex and am just about to stop Aredia, a bisphosphonate like Zometa, after 2 years. The bone strengtheners, by themselves, are not really a tx for bc. There was some initial evidence that they were helpful in slowing bc spread in the bones, but this hasn't really panned out. Most women take it in conjunction with one of the hormonals but not as a stand alone tx. As far as chemo goes, my understanding is that their effectiveness is a very individual thing. Your previous chemos may have not been effective but that doesn't mean Xeloda won't be. As you can see, my knowledge here is limited but I know someone with more experience will be along soon. Take care.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 12:47PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Many of you have made good points re: going to college. Yes, the expenses can be great but by going to community colleges first and then state schools, you can mitigate super high tuitions. The ivy leagues are just outrageous but do provide a great education. Expectations at a high school level and at home are important too. My ex and I graduated from high school about the same time. He lived in a small town in Ohio where only a few people in his class went on to college. They had no counselors to encourage them or talk about financial aid. Most families in the area assumed that if you couldn't pay for it outright, you couldn't go. I grew up in NYC. We had dedicated college counselors who were experts in helping you get into the city or state college system and private universities as well. From early childhood, it never occurred to me not to go to college. My parents and everyone I knew made it clear that education didn't end with high school. To this day, learning anything new is a joy to me! Now, it is quite true that some people may not be on this path but as mrs. devine points out, they generally require some training beyond high school. Those factories and mills that once provided a living wage are no longer a big part of the 21sf century economy. I live in an interesting neighborhood in terms of ethnic demographic and parental expectations. The population is largely Southeast Asian and Mexican. Children are cherished by both of these cultures, however the push for higher education is very strong in the Southeast Asian community but less strong in the Hispanic community. This is not racism or prejudice but statistically confirmed by high school graduation rates and college enrollment. So the expectations of ones family play a big part in this. I'll leave you with one funny joke. As you may know, starting in the early 20th century and continuing until after WWII, there was a huge migration of Eastern European Jews to the US. Learning, first in the religious sense and then in the secular sense, has been a cornerstone of Jewish culture. So the joke goes, What's a Jewish failure? Answer; Someone with a bachelor's degree. Yes, a broad generalization but an indication of how cultural and family expectations influence how higher education is viewed. Caryn

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 11:11AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Lavender, Of course, none of us can predict the personality or bedside manner of the doctor you will be seeing. For all of us and especially for those with greater anxiety, I hope he/she will be forthright about your situation but caring and sensitive in how you are spoken to. My diagnosis happened a bit differently as I met with a multi-disciplinary team after all films and biopsies had been done. As for what to expect, I imagine (and this is not medical certainty, just speculation based on what I know!) the doctor will review all of your mammos and ultrasounds and any other information obtained during previous doctor visits. I am certain you will be physically examined (palpation). I don't know that anyone can tell that a lump is malignant just by touching it. At that point the doctor may recommend a biopsy. If not, and you still feel it's warranted, please speak up and tell your doctor what your concerns are. As for your wedding, congratulations! Even if you need a biopsy, I'm betting that if can be put off until after the wedding. If you've been reading these forums you'll notice that quite often many weeks elapse between the first "bad" mammo or lump finding and a biopsy. I would also be very frank with the doctor about your high anxiety level. It will be OK. If you have BC, then you can begin to develop a plan for treatment if not, then you can enjoy being a newly wed! -Caryn     PS: This is just my opinion on what MIGHT happen. Please don't read anything in to your doctor's behavior if it goes differently.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2012 06:34PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi shrnbrbz, I am sorry that you are having to deal with this. To help you understand the implications of a positive result and the choices you may be facing, if you are positive, I reccommend that you find a center that offers not just the test (which is a simple blood draw) but genetic counseling. Call your primary care pysician or ob/gyn for a referral to a genetic counselor. I had the BRCA test after my bc diagnosis due to familiy history and ethnicity but had to go through genetic counseling and take an on-line class on the BRCA test and all it's implications. I was negative but it was good to know what it all really meant as I have two daughters and a granddaughter. Wishing you the best. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2013 10:18AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I would agree that placement makes a big difference. Mine is on my right side. Some of you may remember that I had the very rare complication of a punctured lung during placement. Actually, a nicked lung which slowly deflated over the course of two weeks, making it an even rarer complication, resulting in 6 days in the hospital and 4 weeks at home with a portable chest tube. Despite that ugly episode, I still love it. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 04:03AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Thank you all for your support. Glenna, juicing is different than making smoothies ( love them too). Juicing literally extracts the liquids from whole veggies and fruits, leaving only a dryish pulp behind. Nothing is added to make it creamy but you can sweeten veggies by adding things like carrots or apples which add a bit of natural sweetness. I also usually add lemon juice and fresh ginger. I really like veggies and just throw in whatever in season organic produce I find at the farmers market. Broccoli, kale and bok choy are some of my favorites. So far the only thing I haven't liked is sweet potato because I thought it made the texture a bit starchy. I borrowed a juicer from my SIL and then bought one of my own which is newer and easier to clean but cleaning is still my only complaint! Caryn

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: As some of you know, I have a single 2cm met to my femur head. My tx has been Anastrozole, rads x15 to the femur met and monthly Aredia. I feel great, work out 5-6 days a week, cleaned up an already decent diet, juice and take D3, glucosimine/chondroitin. I am also on Effexor and Ativan.Went back to work 5 weeks ago and am thrilled to be back. I have gone to Stanford, twice, for second opinions. My Stanford MO and my Kaiser MO know each other and consult easily. The Stanford MO brought up the possibility of doing chemo with curative intent. This is based on a 1996 study of women with limited metastaic bc. The study involved 1,581 subjects of different ages, menopausal status, ER status and area of mets. A small percentage of the subjects, across the board, achieved complete remission. I am currently wading through the study to pick out what percentage of those women most closely resemble me. My Kaiser MO said she would be willing to give it a go, using ACT, but it was up to me. She said and Stanford doc agrees, that there is no clear " right" choice. So, do I continue along a tx path that regards my disease as a chronic condition or do I gamble, with poor odds, on going for an initially harsher tx that may, or may not, pay off in the long run. I have a PET scheduled for next Weds. but my MO doesn't think it will provide ant major info to factor into my decision, unless I've had progression, which she doubts. I really value all input especially stage IV sisters since you all understand the emotional component of this. My gut, BTW, says to stay the course and not do chemo right now but this is definitely crazy making. Caryn Bilateral mx 9/7/11 with one step ns reconstruction. Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2012 08:52PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Chris, I am on a similar treatment plan as most who have already responded. I had rads to my bone met (upper femur) and take Arimidex. I did a year of monthly Aredia infusions and will now move to an every three months schedule. Aromatase inhibitors, such as Aromasin, Femara and Arimidex are generally used for post-menopausal, ER+ patients. Tamoxifen for those who are pre-menopausal, though there are no rules set in stone. It is also very common to use these drugs in conjunction with a bisphosphonate such as Aredia or Zometa . Ask about that as well as better pain relief. Wishing you the best. Caryn

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2015 09:17PM - edited Mar 22, 2015 09:20PM by exbrnxgrl ally, Don't think about what you could have done in the past. Women who have breast cancer have lived, super healthy lifestyles, moderate lifestyles and dreadful ones. Neither diet nor exercise, yoga, meditation or religion is guarantee of protection from bc. So don't spend another moment going down that path. I think about the fact that I have stage IV bc everyday, it is always there. Sometimes it is a dark shadow, sometimes I am proud. Yes, proud! As in times when I do something that you wouldn't think a stage IV person could do. However, the thought of bc does not stop me from happily carrying on with the rest of my life. I refuse to be emotionally crippled by bc as I simply have too many goodthings to enjoy in life. I think that with time, many of us get to this point so be gentle with yourself , and you'll find a way there too. Caryn

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2019 09:28AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I’m writing the same thing as many others, but look at it as supporting anecdotal evidence 😉. - Funny, you don’t look sick! Yes, I look very, very normal but I still have MBC. Trust me on this one. - You a great attitude and that’s why you’ve done well. Yes, I have always been optimistic. Although I think it’s made my life easier and more pleasant, I don’t believe it’s kept me from progression. If that were the case, many with “good attitudes” would still be alive today. - But, we have no family history of bc! With what is currently known about genetic connections means that the vast majority of us dx’ed with bc have no genetic mutations. There may other genes, yet to be discovered, but currently, most of us will test negative for genetic mutations. - if your bc metastasizes to another part of your body, i.e. liver, lungs, bone, then you have cancer of that location. No! If you have bc mets, you still have bc, but it has spread to other organs. You do not have bone cancer, liver cancer etc. It will be treated as breast cancer. - If you are dx’ed with stage IV bc, you will die quickly. While this is sadly true for some, more and more of us are living longer with good QOL.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2013 04:23AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Chickadee, I'm not an expert but I think all of the major port manufacturers, Medi-port, Port-a-cath and Bard, make power injectable ports. I would recommend these because in addition to infusions, the can be used for blood draws and imaging injections. I have a Bard power port. It is small, they make a petite model.All that is visible are three small bumps arranged in a triangular pattern under my skin. Mine was placed in the hollow between my shoulder and chest and is not visible unless I'm wearing spaghetti straps. It's very comfortable and I can sleep in any position. Installation is a simple procedure and can be done by a general surgeon. I love mine and given that I'm stage IV, have no intention of ever having it removed. Sorry to hear about the progression :( Keepingon, Most of the time PICC lines are inserted for short term usage, like needing IV antibiotics for a few weeks.That is why you don't see many women here who have them, at least in the US. Once healed, ports require no care or special treatment. They are flushed when you have infusions or blood draws. If they aren't going to be used for long periods of times they still need to be flushed but this is quick and easy process that the infusion nurses do. Caryn

Posts.Content: exbrnxgrl wrote: Almost 4 years ago, I had rads to my upper femur, quite close to the groin. It did it's job in rendering a bone met necrotic, hooray! A little less than two years ago, I noticed considerable ankle swelling after a very long flight. I wasn't too concerned and it resolved quickly. Sometime after that, the same thing happened after another long flight. Again, not much concern. Then, it happened again last summer but did not resolve quickly. I saw my doctor and she suggested light compression after ultrasound showed no blood clot. The compression worked fairly well, through most of my school year, but by spring, the swelling was not well controlled and was moving up my leg. With school out, the swelling is less pronounced, since I'm not on my feet as much, but flares on days I am more active. More doctor visits, ultrasounds, vascular specialist etc. Verdict! LE induced by those long ago rads.i was fitted for a custom compression garment (open toe, single leg chaps) and await their arrival. It was interesting to see the consultations between vascular specialist, RO and mo. RO being the final word and saying, yes, rads in that area could induce leg LE (mo thought not!). I have no pain, save for occasional achiness at the ankle and I am grateful that rads killed the met. Still, it's one more unwanted souvenir of bc, and, from a vanity POV, it is ugly! Ah well. ** Ironically, I was very diligent about my arm compression on every flight. Bilateral mx 9/7/11 with one step ns reconstruction. Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 04:07PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I had rads x15 to the femur. Have been on Arimidex since Nov. 21 and am having monthly Aredia infusions. No se's from the Arimidex, so far. I'm juicing lots of green veggies, which I actually like ( but hate cleaning the juicer). Also taking vitamin D3, glucosimine/chondroitin and pro-biotics. Excuse me if I sound a bit giddy but the last few months have been difficult. I was afraid that I'd never feel like me again or that bc would somehow rob me of who I am. Maybe someday, but not yet...

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 04:45AM - edited Sep 28, 2011 04:46AM by exbrnxgrl Hi Ladies, For all of you preparing for surgery, keep your hospital bag packing to a minimum. I would recommend not bringing your own pj's and robe to the hospital. It is much easier to accommodate an IV with the snap shoulder gowns supplied by the hospital than with your own. Use a second gown with the opening in front to function as a robe for hall walking. Lip balm was a must if you have dry lips but my throat has never bothered me after surgery. I am not a back sleeper so I found that a U shaped neck pillow made back sleeping easier for me. Face wipes were good for freshening up but I didn't use the body wipes until I got home because the nurse's aides gave me daily sponge baths. My hospital worked hard to create a healing environment and there were signs all over asking people to be quiet. It worked! I have never been in such a quiet hospital. The hospital stay goes quickly and most hospitals provide all of your needs so focus more on what you will need as you recover at home. Love and positive thoughts to you all. Caryn

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 11:46AM - edited Jul 13, 2012 01:12PM by exbrnxgrl Ha, ha and don't forget the hazmat suit as well :) I have had only conventional treatment and am currently NED. I really like all of my medical team and have never felt like I was duped, lied to or pushed into anything I didn't fully understand or want to do. I did get rid of my first mo because I could not achieve that kind of relationship with him. That being said, I have fine tuned my diet, but still allow my self to have so called forbidden foods, in moderation on occasion. I do take a bunch of supplements as well and am always interested in learning about anything that might help me live well longer. I guess you could say I am taking the complementary route. Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 11:48AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Chickadee, Thanks for bringing us back to the op. Your post is very thought provoking. Your experience and comments on conventional doctors resonates with me. I have had both good and not so good conventional docs. If I am not comfortable with a doctor my solution is simple, I find a new one. I decided after my bmx, after my stage IV dx that I didn't really like my mo. My RO, who I love, recommended someone else and he was right, she is great. I realize that since I live in an urban area and belong to a huge HMO, I have the luxury of these choices. I realize that this is a privilege not everyone has. Additionally, I have always believed that I am an equal partner of my treatment team. If a doctor treats me as anything less than that, I move on. Of course, this does involve a great deal of responsibility on my part. I read, research and never hesitate to ask questions. The docs I have chosen respect me for that. Lastly, like you, I would never paint an entire profession with such a broad brush. It is simply not fair . As to alternative practitioners, I have never used one, but if I find myself in that position (strong believer in never knowing what I would do until I've walked in those shoes), I will use the same criteria as I use for conventional, to the extent that it's possible. Caryn

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2015 01:18AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I ended up not having chemo, but had two years of Pamidronate infusions. My center is large (probably 30 chairs and several closed rooms with beds). All the chairs are nice recliners with privacy curtains and individual TV's. The rooms are light, bright and there are windows on the outer walls. There is a patient kitchen with juices, soups, light snacks and facilities for warming food you may have brought from home. If you're not comfortable with your mo or any aspect of your care, please seek a second opinion

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 08:34PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Susan, Hope you checked out the packing/tips list on surgery thread. You'll notice we are all different and what is a must for one woman is not important fo another. CLC mentions the Amoema cami. The make more than one model. I found the one that looks like a stretchy tank top (in black,white, or nude) to be perfect and can be worn as a plain tank top when you remove the drain pockets. Since my ps did not let me shower until the drains were removed, I didn't worry about lanyards or pins. As for the gym, after my drains were out, 10 days, I was given permission to do light treadmill and recumbent bike work. You surgeon will wrap you in some kind of garment or bra so just bring a loose button front top to slip over it. My biggest hope for you is that after the surgery, when you get final path report that you don't need chemo. Remember, it is the oncologist, not the bs, who interprets the report and makes recommendations based on the path report. Best of luck to you! Caryn

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 03:29AM exbrnxgrl wrote: I'm going to hop in on your juicing conversation. Prices vary widely from under $100.00 to several hundred. There are basically two types, masticating and centrifugal. You will need a masticating juicer if you want to juice wheat grass. I borrowed an old Jack LaLane juicer just to see if I liked juicing. It was huge, loud and a pain to clean but I loved the juice. I read lots of reviews and compared prices. For my money, the Breville Compact Juice Fountain was the winner. Compact is a bit of a misnomer since none are too small but it's smaller than many. It is a centrifugal juicer but does a good job on leafy greens and everything else I throw into it. I do not peel, core or cut most things as the feed chute is pretty wide. Citrus fruit is the exception since I find the peels produce a bit of juice that is too bitter for me. I juice lots of kale, broccoli and Chinese greens. Add a small apple and a couple of carrots to sweeten it a bit. A slice of fresh ginger is geat too. Bonus, the pulp Is great for composting. Warning, most juices turn a mucky green once you add a green veggie. Doesn't look great but is so light and fresh that I look forward to it each day. There may be a juicing thread somewhere on bco. Happy juicing! Caryn PS: I buy all produce at from organic vendors at a local farmers market

Posts.Content: May 12, 2016 09:09AM exbrnxgrl wrote: indenial, Try not to spend too much time dwelling on past treatment, or what might have been different if only.... The reality is that 25-30% of those diagnosed at an earlier stage develop mets. The disease has no respect for age, or prior tx. It happens to us at all ages and stages of our lives, despite our best efforts to control it. Although you're overwhelmed right now Istrongly recommend a second opinion at the best facility you can get to. It will really help with treatment decisions and give you more confidence in your tx plan. As for aggressive tx, more is not always better. Some of us with limited bone mets who are ER+ have done very well on anti-hormonals alone. I had rads to my femur and an AI, no aggressive chemo , or any chemo at all for that matter. I live an almost normal life. However, we are all different and a second opinion will be of great help and give you confidence in whatever tx is proposed.Take care.

Posts.Content: 6 hours ago exbrnxgrl wrote: Ladies, My mets were found completely by accident (long story), about six weeks after my BMI, staged II b. I had no symptoms. According to studies, I won’t live any longer due to finding mets early, I’ll just know about it longer. I think you can look at vigilant monitoring both ways. Constant scanning and bloodwork are very stressful for many. People forget to live while they “fight”. On the other hand, some find vigilant monitoring comforting. I think you need to go for whatever comforts you, and doesn’t heighten your anxiety and stress. It took me a while, but I have greatly reduced the frequency of my scans and my mo never did tumor markers. I’m good with it now and my stress levels are way down

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 06:57PM - edited Jan 29, 2013 07:49PM by exbrnxgrl Renae, You could spend lots of precious time beating yourself up and trying to figure out why you got bc. The answer is simple; no one really knows! It is likely that there is no single factor but a combination that creates the perfect storm, so to speak. Other than to benefit those who come after you, what would be the point in discovering what caused your bc? By the time you're stage IV, you want to live as well as you can. You may have a short time or a long time left (hopefully the latter), don't waste it on things that don't matter now. BTW, if this is eating at you, consider counseling and anti-depressants. I have been on Effexor since early on in my dx. I work full time and live, almost, as I did before bc. It won't last forever but I'm going to enjoy it! Take good care of yourself. Caryn

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 03:11AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Since we're already veering ot...although, overall more students are entering college after high school graduation, about 73% as of the 2012 graduating class, only about 53% receive a bachelors degree within six years of starting. Here's why college is important. In order to remain competitive in the world market , and our economy is global, the advantage goes to those who are prepared for 21st century jobs. Those jobs most often require the level of expertise that comes with a college degree. That's not to say that every job requires a college degree but the types of jobs that the global economy requires increasingly do. As for there being no jobs, we have just come out of an economic low. Hiring is on the uptick and the jobless rate is declining (not fast enough for some, but declining never the less). I live in Silicon Valley and our slump was major yet now, anyone who has a degree in areas related to the high tech industry is having a fairly easy time finding a job. Yet workers from other countries with HB1 visas are filling some of those jobs because we are not producing enough graduates in some tech areas. Yes, there will always be some jobs for those with high school diplomas, but fewer in number and salaries for many of those jobs, especially in the service industry are low paying.We need to educate students for the way the world economy is, not what it was. Yes, there are success stories without college and failures with college but the need for higher education in the 21st century is a reality. As an educator, you could argue my bias, and I would heartily agree, but part of my job as an educator is to look at where we're going in terms of what students need. What do we need to give them to prepare them for not only their future but our nation's future? How do we get them ready to compete in the global,economy? The answer is clear, higher education. Why set the bar low when we can set it high? Caryn, a very passionate teacher :)

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2016 03:00PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Sue, I have never had IV chemo yet still have my port. Here's what happened. - Had port installed in anticipation of chemo. I was staged IIB and set to do a clinical trial. - Had to do an echocardiogram for trial. Fluid found around my heart. - Fluid turns out to be nothing, but spot found on femur. - After the whole pneumothorax mess is resolved, biopsy shows 2cm bc met on upper femur. - A decision is made to nuke the met with rads, go on an AI and do Aredia infusions for two years. Aredia is an older bone strengthener. So, I used the port for Aredia only. I continue to use it for scans and blood draws. Since it doesn't bother me or show, I've chosen to leave it in, knowing I will probably need it one day. Despite the fact that I am not superstitious, there is a part of me that thinks the minute I remove it, I'll have progression. So as irrational as it seems, it's a bit of a talisman for me. Don't laugh 🤗.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2018 05:44PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Tigerlily, Breast cancer is complicated. There are many possibles types of breast cancer, and even within a given type, different hormone profiles. That is a very simplistic explanation, but my point is, breast cancer is far from a single profile disease. Tumor size and lymph node involvement are not related and breast cancer can metastasize through the blood stream as well as the lymph system. It’s almost impossible to say if lymph nodes are involved at your stage so guessing “likelihood “ is pointless. You mentioned no family history, but the majority of breast cancer patients have no family history . PET scans are very expensive and expose one to radiation so it’s not usual for someone with suspected early stage bc to have one, but I can’t say it’s never done. My counsel at this point is to not get ahead of yourself. Please wait until you know what you are dealing with (hopefully it’s benign), and then you can learn specifics based on your particular type of bc. Wishing you the best!

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 06:22PM - edited Jun 5, 2015 07:02PM by exbrnxgrl So, after thinking about this, I thought, perhaps, I wasn't 100% sure of the definition of chronic. Here's what I found: Not to be confused with Chronic toxicity. A chronic condition is a human health condition or disease that is persistent or otherwise long-lasting in its effects or a disease that comes with time.[1] The term chronic is usually applied when the course of the disease lasts for more than three months.[1] Common chronic diseases include arthritis, asthma, cancer, COPD, diabetes and viral diseases such as hepatitis C and HIV/AIDS. In medicine, the opposite of chronic is acute. A chronic course is further distinguished from a recurrent course; recurrent diseases relapse repeatedly, with periods of remission in between. The non-communicable diseases are also usually lasting medical conditions but are separated by their non-infectious causes. In contrast, some chronic diseases, such as HIV/AIDS, are caused by transmissible infections. Chronic diseases constitute a major cause of mortality and the World Health Organization (WHO) reports chronic non-communicable conditions to be by far the leading cause of mortality in the world, representing 35 million deaths in 2005 and over 60% of all diseases. - Source; Wikipedia. By this definition, chronic disease does not carry a promise of survivability. When my mo mentioned chronic, I thought long term, but I never thought there was a promise of cure or even 20 years, just some undefined lengthy period of time. Yes, I would love a cure, but I'm ok with chronic, for now (but I still think it was a puff piece

My doctors, both surgeon and ps, gave me all the options, scenarios, pros and cons. At a post surgical check up, my ps asked what I wanted to do about the missing nipple. I told him, that as of now, nothing. I was in no mood for any more surgeries. He was quiet for a moment and then said that he used to think that all patients would want to be as complete as possible after mx but over the years he has learned that is not true and he honors each woman's choice. Couldn't you just kiss this guy? He really is a gem in acknowledging that recon and being made "whole" is not for everyone. Caryn

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2016 12:26AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Patty, I think most major brands these days are power injectable ports. They allow two importsnt things; injection of tracer materials, such as those used for PET scans (just used mine this morning) and blood draws. No more needle sticks or searching for veins! Of course these functions can only be performed by port trained nurses (not lab techs). My medical facility alway asks if port access is needed for scans and I have my blood draws at the infusion center. They are well set up to use the power port for all it's intended ways. Some have reported getting power ports and then going to facilities which don't make trained personnel available except for actual infusions. Another thought on port placement is the upper arm. Not as common, but several women I know have had it placed there. Take care.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2016 01:42AM - edited Mar 24, 2016 01:48AM by exbrnxgrl Ronniekay, My story is unusual. They did know what treatment I was getting, (it was to be IV chemo whether in the trial or not) as I was supposed to go into a clinical trial and was thought to be stage IIB. When the PET scan was done, to figure out what the fluid around my heart was, they discovered 1) a completely collapsed right lung 2) a spot on my femur. Yes, I hit the jackpot! After the collapsed lung was dealt with, a biopsy confirmed that the spot on my femur was bc. So... I was out of the trial, out of any proposed stage IIB chemo and on to tx for stage IV, which has been an AI, rads to the bone met and two years of Aredia. Coming up on 5 years and still NED. As to why I have such a stealth port, with no visible line, and only palpation bumps visible, I can't say. I rarely know it's there and neither does anyone else. PS: the fluid around my heart is still there but is idiopathic and unchanged. It is evaluated every time I have a scan.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2017 03:13PM - edited Mar 25, 2017 07:20PM by exbrnxgrl Are you sure that you're having a radical bmx? Those are rarely done these days. it involves removal of the underlying chest (pectoral) muscles and is no longer in common use. I had a bmx with axillary node dissection on one side. I don't remember toileting difficulties, though I moved slowly and gently in the beginning. I did use moist wipes. A radical would be far more debilitating, but is very much the exception, so check with your surgeon and best of luck. PS: I did some googling and found that radical mastectomies fell out of favor in the 1970's and is only used under unusual circumstances. Having all muscles removed is not only extreme and disfiguring but would certainly have a major impact on range of motion.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 01:52PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I don't think regrets or even guilt, in and of themselves are such a bad thing. There are lessons to be learned from them. I do think they cause a problem when they become a crippling force in your life and you can't move beyond them. As for medical or tx regrets, I have been fortunate. My doctors were always upfront about risks to any procedure or tx and I researched them as well. I had a very bad, though rare, complication from port placement, a collapsed lung. However, I knew there was a 1% chance this would happen. I almost laughed because the cances were so small. I also had a rough time getting it to re-inflate (3 separate chest tube insertions, 6 days in the hospital and almost 1 month with a portable chest tube). Regrets? No! I love my port now and would never use my experience to warn someone against getting one. Neither I nor any medical professional can predict ahead of time if one will be in the group that suffers an adverse event, even if the chance is only 1%. Caryn

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2018 10:48AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Let me first say that I have never had chemo, so I have no first hand experience with it (long story, but mets to my bone was discovered and I have only been on anti-hormonales). Before I was known to be stage IV, chemo was planned and my mo said I shouldn't work because I am a teacher of young children, but many can and do work during chemo. Please reach out to any and all social services programs that can provide support (rides to chemo, cleaning for a cause etc.) to help lighten the load. The American Cancer Socity and your hospital social worker can be good resources. If you have two types of aggressive cancer, I'm not sure why you feel you likely won't have metastasis in the future, though no one has a crystal ball. Depending on your specific dx, your chances may vary, statistically, but “feeling" that you likely don't/won't have mets now or in the future is not a factor. FWIW, I had a very indolent grade 1 tumor and much to everyone's surprise I already had a bone met. My point is that there is still so much that remains a mystery about bc, so please consider the fact that you already know your bc is aggressive. Ultimately, you are the driver and you have every right to make the choices you want. But please consider not just where you're at right now, but where you'll be long term . All the best

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2018 09:13AM exbrnxgrl wrote: This is not unusual, as you can see by everyone’s posts. My best advice is to do what is comfortable for you and know your audience i.e. be honest but circumspect with those who may want to give unsolicited or negative advice. I also felt very empowered by controlling the narrative. I made it known, from the beginning that if anyone had questions or concerns they needed to ask me directly. If I could, I answered openly and honestly. If I was not comfortable discussing certain things I politely stated as much. I made it very clear that I abhor gossip, speculation and unsolicited medical and non-medical advice. In the end, I’m nor sure that all unwelcome advice can be stopped, but I’m glad you recognize that it is often well intended, however misguided it seems at the time. Take care

I have been on Arimidex since late November and monthly infusion of Aredia. Hopefully someone who has been dealing with this longer will be along soon. Hope you're not having any pain or se's. Caryn
Posts.Title: connect other with bone mets keephealth cookie97

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 10:28PM exbrnxgrl wrote: I have told very few people, outside of family and close friends, that I am stage IV. However most everyone involved in my life knows I have bc, had a bmx, collapsed lung, rads etc. So, they still say I look great. When I first went back to work, people were almost shocked that I didn't look sick at all. Can you imagine if they knew I was stage IV?  Actually, I don't mind too much what others say since I know that they mean well and it is, after all, an uncomfortable situation for many. Anger has never been part of my personality and I'm sure not going to let bc take that from me.   Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2015 02:18PM exbrnxgrl wrote: josalive, Welcome! Waiting for results is, for me, far worse than pre-scan waiting. So, cozy up on one of our sofas and enjoy the snack or beverage of your choice:) Techs are not radiologists and though experienced ones may be good at understanding the scans, they are not trained to interpret them, just perform them correctly so the radiologist can interpretthem. Don't try to read anything into their behavior or you might drive yourself crazy. I get an email notification when my scan results are available,,but that doesn't stop me from checking a million times before that. Wishing you the best.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2014 12:39PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Second opinions are always good. I am uncomfortable with docs who give us a timeline as no one has a crystal ball. As for telling people, that is a highly individual decision. Sounds as if you have some regrets about some of your "telling" already, but if you were simply being honest, you have no control over someone else's reactions. So, only you can decide who/how much to tell. I have never been dishonest about my situation but have chosen to keep it low key at work. BC and stage IV in particular are more complex than most people realize and I just don't have the time or inclination to explain it all. At this point, I look quite well and live a fairly normal life. That won't always be so and as I feel the need to tell more people I will. BTW, if someone asks me point blank about my bc or says something like "But you're ok now, right?" I always  tell them the truth.   Wishing  you the best.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2014 11:15AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Scrappy, I am so sorry to hear that you got this news. Every time we have progression, it does take a while to digest but eventually we just pull up our big girl panties and go on. Excuse me for asking, but I am a bit confused about your condition. Do you have bone and liver cancer (primaries) or a metastasis of breast cancer? If they are mets of bc, they are treated as breast cancer and still considered bc so you do not have bone or liver cancer. Bone and liver cancer are entirely different and treated differently. I have bone mets and have done well. I know we have members with liver mets and a thread dedicated to that. I know someone will be along soon to help you out. Take care.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2015 10:19PM exbrnxgrl wrote: kebab, I drove like a madwomanto the Starbucks diagonally across from the campus (Homestead at Lawrence Epwy.). I must have looked half crazed, that's how much I need my morning hoe! So now, the waiting games commences for both of us. Shoes are now well organized and 10 pairs are going. Younger dd came over and took two pairs. Will offer the others to older dd and then donate anything that's left. I even went with younger dd to Walmart, a place I detest, but it kept me occupied. I'm home alone now and mentally reviewing past time frames for learning results (usually 24 hours at most). I may have to take my dogs on a very long walk. Grrrrr, I hate this. Good luck to you as we wait together. Caryn

I am sorry not to address everyone personally, but (sadly) there are too many of us, work is insanely busy and there's lots of activity buzzing around my younger dd and SIL as we enter the final weeks before the birth of baby Miles. Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2015 07:15PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Well, it is clear that I started this thread with selfish motives. I don't get nervous before scans, though I often develop mysterious aches and pains in the days leading up to a scan. I had a PET this morning and now is when major scanxiety kicks in. Results...I feel like the very balance of my life rests on them and I'm unable toproperly focus on anything until I know them. I ran to Starbucks immediately afterward and would have injected the coffee through my port if that had been possible. Then a bit of retail therapy and in a few minutes, I'll be doing a major shoe purge. My walk in closet has turned in to a trip in closet and, honestly, I have lots of shoes I never wear. I hope to hear from my mo within 24, per usual, but until then, I plan to keep busy, busy, busy. Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2015 06:28PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Jobur, Given the fact that you haven't eaten for at least 6 hours, feeling shaky sounds par for the course. At my medical center, I get tucked into a bed and am given warm blankets. They turn out the lights and I take a nice nap, no talking allowed! After the scan, I eat immediately and if it's the morning, I must have a good, strong coffee. Funny how every center is different.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2015 11:48PM - edited Jul 20, 2015 12:04AM by exbrnxgrl Diana, I have an amusing story about spinal taps (if such a thing is even possible). When I was in the Peace Corps, in 1978, I woke up one day with an unimaginably painful headache. I'm a bit fuzzy on exactly what happened, but I ended up in the USAID dispensary, the closest thing there was to a Western hospital in country. I can't even find words to describe how excruciating that headache was. They pumped me full of some kind of drugs that left me conscious but very, very loopy. I'm they told me they were going to do a spinal tap but (I am told) that I giggled incessantly and kept asking them to cut my head off. I do remember that I had to lay flat for a long period of time and I had more pain meds. But after the tap, my headache was gone. Turns out I had meningitis and my head was not cut off 😊

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 06:39PM - edited Jun 5, 2015 06:40PM by exbrnxgrl The downside to message boards, and internet communication in general, is that virtually all other cues that facilitate our understanding of someone else's words, feelings, attitudes and emotions are absent. Sincerity would be particularly hard to gage. Throw in the fact that we're dealing with advanced bc, and the potential exists for lots of misunderstandings and dust ups. I know that my words have been misconstrued from time to time. It's just a limitation of the medium.  BTW, this may be selfish, but since I feel like my time on earth may be limited, I've just tried to find the best medical care I could, do what I need to mitigate se's and live my life with happiness. Do I wish there were a better way? Of course, but I'd be lying if I said I'm going to put a lot of my time and energy into being a crusader for those things. I admire those who can and do, but that's not where my talents lie.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2014 11:03AM - edited Apr 28, 2014 11:07AM by exbrnxgrl No one can physically prevent anyone from posting to stage IV, as it currently stands. The key word in the forum header is respect. How one chooses to show respect, is of course, subjective though my hope is that one would take the more conservative approach. Here is a response from the mods to me , via pm, when I sought clarification about posting on stage IV. Ironically, I was just a few short weeks away from my own stage IV dx. "This is a forum for those who are braving more treatment and managing the ups and downs of a stage IV or metastatic breast cancer diagnosis. Their caring supporters are welcome as well. Thank you for respecting their very special space and for your sensitivity." Regards, Judith and the Mods This was in the Fall of 2011. It does leave room for one to interpret the meaning of respect. I chose to go the conservative route (but little did I know...). It just didn't seem that important for me to post on stage IV when their issues were not mine and there were so many other threads that were more pertinent at the time. Just how I feel and I hope this doesn't turn into a big dust up again. As someone who is stage IV, this is the last thing I want to spend my time on (and housework).

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2015 08:43PM - edited Mar 13, 2015 09:10PM by exbrnxgrl Let me start by saying that every family, ultimately, makes their own decisions on this subject. However as an educator (mostly teaching grades 1 and K) I strongly urge parents to tell their children the truth , at an age appropriate level. Here is why; Children are very intuitive and very sensitive to changes in their household, but they lack the emotional maturity, life experience and context in which to frame, cope and understand these things. So, unless you are an amazing actor or you lie to cover up what's happening, your child will know that something is not right. They may not verbalize it, but the stress and anxiety will surface in some way. Five is not too young. The American Cancer Society is a good resource for info on how to speak to children about cancer. Though I teach first grade now, I taught kindergarten for 8 years. When a major family problem occurred, I saw parents who openly, and appropriately, dealt with it by telling their children. I saw, a very few, who chose to say nothing. Without going into detail, the children who knew what was happening in their family had a much easier time than children kept in the dark. I feel very, very strongly about this and though I can't tell your husband what to do, I'd be happy to tell him the possible repercussions of keeping a child in the dark. My best wishes are with you and your family. Caryn PS: if your daughter is in school, please let her teacher know what's happening

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2013 08:51PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi Gina, Welcome but sorry you've had to join our club. I had a bone biopsy to my femoral head. It was done by an interventional radiologist. I had conscious sedation, via IV. Love that Versed! I think there was probably some type of pain medication in the IV as well. The area where the biopsy was to be taken was numbed with a local an anesthetic. It felt like I was conscious, I was able to talk and respond to questions, but felt no discomfort . Versed has some amnesiac properties, so my memory of it is fuzzy, though at the time I thought I was very alert. It took less than an hour, once I was prepped. I was monitored for about and 60-90 minutes afterwards. I was very hungry and devoured a turkey sandwich and cranberry juice while I rested. The site was closed by a small band aid and was only slightly sore the next day. Wishing you all the best. Caryn

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2014 11:18AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Sunny, Your intent is great and, as said, we have all asked this question. Yes, we could conduct our own surveys, but they would just be anecdotal. It would be very difficult for us to isolate cause and effect in anything but the most casual way, since it would be hard to control for many other factors in a casual survey. Once we have been dx'ed with bc, focusing on the tx does become a priority for the vast majority of us. As for prevention, of either an initial bc or recurrence, many, many researchers have looked at it with very few tangible conclusions. That is what is so frustrating and why it feels like a real crapshoot (you will see this phrase crop up regularly). Keep reading through both the conventional and alternative threads and you will see many different theories and approaches to diet and lifestyle. However, there seems to be little commonality when it comes to "success". For instance, I have used only conventional tx, with some supplements and had been NED for 4 years. My bone met is necrotic and I've had no progression. My diet has always been healthy, but not extreme. If I want to eat or drink something, I do and never feel a bit of guilt. I believe in moderation, not compulsion. My younger sister was dx'ed with uterine cancer at age 50. She led a compulsively clean lifestyle since her early 20's. Not only with respect to food, but no antiperspirants, plastics, microwaves etc. She was thin and exercised. She was dead within 4 months of her dx. Just another anecdote, but a good illustration of why anecdotes and casual surveys may not yield the answers we are looking for.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 04:43PM exbrnxgrl wrote: Hi jojo38, I understand the emotions that are crashing through you. Let me understand; you are ER and PR negative ( that is why doc says other drugs won't work), your bs wants you to have neo- adjuvant therapy? Do you know your HER2 status? Have you seen an oncologist? I am not saying your bs is wrong, but an oncologist should be making the tx choices. Also, as you are scheduled to have quite a few scans, more information effecting tx choices may be known after the scans. As far as other people go, you may be surprised to find out how kind and generous they can be. I am a first grade teacher in a close school community. While not revealing every nitty gritty detail of my disease, I was very open and honest. I controlled the information so there was nothing to gossip or whisper about. Everyone was amazing (except one or two!).I would also urge you to be as open and honest with your daughter as you can on an age appropriate level. When children don't know what's going on, that's when they worry and are vulnerable to stress and anxiety. The American Cancer Society web site has some good ideas and resources to help with talking to children about cancer. Please let us know as much as possible about your bc by allowing your diagnosis line to show at the bottom of your posts. This will help people to give you advice and support. Wishing you the best. Caryn

Posts.Title: Funeral on Saturday and asked to wear pink.... bottkota

Posts.Content: May 23, 2015 09:07AM - edited May 23, 2015 09:09AM by exbrnxgrl Ah the pink thing... Like manyof you, I'm just not into it. When I have been given pink related stuff, I say thank you (because the intention was good) and then don't use it. Two of my former students made me a pink ribbon print fleece blanket. They were only in second grade. It was so very sweet and I would never get upset, however, my younger dd has it because she likes snuggling up on her couch with it. If adults ask me why I'm not on the pink bandwagon, I calmly tell them and leave it at that. As a result, four years into this, I rarely get pink stuff. Time is really a great help. I also don't want pity or attention, so in the beginning, I kept my dx relatively quiet. Over the last year, I've casually dropped it in to conversation if the topic of bc came up. I even mentioned it on FB and, much to my surprise, got very little reaction, either way. After 4 years, no one brings me food, but it was very helpful after my surgery ( no left overs, all delicious and fresh!) especially for my dd's who were helping care for me. They didn't have to worry about shopping and cooking. I should add that because I don't "look" like I have bc and still work, travel etc. people probably are a bit baffled by my condition. I realize that I am fortunate, for now, but my future is still quite uncertain, as we all know. Mostly, I try not to fritter too much of my time, energy or emotions on what others think. That's my rant!

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 06:52PM exbrnxgrl wrote: My dear ally, And fed up you should be! Get thee to another, better onc immediately. Laugh at you, act like the particulars of your dx are something for only them to know? Banish them to the far ends of the universe and never let them come back. I hope the next onc you see welcomes questions, provides you with as much detailed info about your particular bc as you want/need and understands that you are as much a part of the treatment team as they are. Are we terminal? Statistically, it is likely we will die of bc. But the statistics are ever changing as are the number of years we are likely to survive and...those are aggregate stats. How you, as an individual respond to tx, may differ from the aggregate. I just don't think that any onc worth his/her salt should have you dead and buried at this point. Good luck with the appointment! Caryn

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 10:38AM exbrnxgrl wrote: Sorry about the hair loss, Ann. I haven't had a tx that caused that yet but I'm sure I will eventually. When I thought I was having chemo I bought a wig and a halo hairpiece. Never wore them for more than a few minutes to try them on but they're sitting in a drawer for my use one day. Yesterday, our 5th graders came back from science camp, A girl who has alopecia , and always wore a hat or wig, stepped off the bus wearing a nice pair of earrings and a big smile. She had never appeared at school without her head covered but looked so happy and confident that I almost cried. She had been in my kindergarten class and we spent a lot of time educating both parents and students about alopecia. I know this is very different from chemo induced baldness but it did make me think of many of my bco sisters and the role hair places in our lives. Sorry to get off topic. Caryn
